Play details
The insatiate countesse. Genre: Tragedy. Date first published: 1613. Date first performed: 1607-1608 ?

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div2.stage: The Countesse of Sweuia discouered sitting at a Table couered with blacke, on which stands two blacke Tapers lighted, she in mourning.
Enter Roberto Count of Cypres, Gvido Count of Arsena, and Signior Mizaldvs.

sp.speaker: Mizaldus.
sp.p:
What should we do in this Countess's dark hole?
She is sullenly retired, as the Turtle:
Every day has been a black day with her since
her husband dyed, and what should we unruly
members make here?

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
As melancholy night masques up heaven's face,
So doth the Evening-star present herself
Unto the careful Shepherd's gladsome eyes,
By which unto the fold he leads his flock.

sp.speaker: Mizald.
sp.p:
Zounds what a sheepish beginning is here? it is
said true, Love is simple; and it may well hold, and thou art a
simple lover.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.p:
See how yond Star like beauty in a cloud,
Illumines darkness, and beguiles the Moon
Of all her glory in the firmament.

sp.speaker: Mizal.
sp.p:
Well said man in the Moon. Was ever such Astronomers?
Marry I fear none of these will fall into the right Ditch.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ha Anna, what are my doors unbarred?

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.p: I will assure you the way into your Ladyship is open.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
And God defend that any profane hand
Should offer sacrilege to such a Saint.
Lovely Isabella, by this duteous kiss,
That draws part of my Soul along with it,
Had I but thought my rude intrusion
Had waked the Dove-like spleen harboured within you,
Life and my first born should not satisfy
Such a transgression, worthy of a check,
But that Immortals wink at my offence,
Makes me presume more boldly: I am come
To raise you from this so infernal sadness.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
My Lord of Cypres, do not mock my grief:
Tears are as due a Tribute to the dead,
As fear to God, and duty unto Kings,
Love to the Just, or hate unto the Wicked.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.p:
Surcease.
Believe it is a wrong unto the Gods:
They sail against the wind that wail the dead.
And since his heart hath wrestled with deaths pangs,
From whose stern Cave none tracts a backward path.
Leave to lament this necessary change,
And thank the Gods, for they can give as good.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I wail his loss! Sink him ten cubits deeper,
I may not fear his resurrection:
I will be sworn upon the holy Writ
I mourn thus servant cause, he died no sooner:
He buried me alive,
And mewed me up like Cretan Dedalus,
And with wall-eyed Jealousy kept me from hope
Of any waxen wings to fly to pleasure.
But now his soul her Argos eyes hath closed,
And I am free as air. You of my sex,
In the first flow of youth use you the sweets
Due to your proper beauties, ere the ebb
And long wain of unwelcome change shall come.
Fair women play: she is chaste whom none will have.
Here is a man of a most mild aspect,
Temperate, effeminate, and worthy love,
One that with burning ardour hath pursued me:
A donative he hath of every God;
Apollo gave him locks, Jove his high front,
The God of Eloquence his flowing speech,
The feminine Deities strowed all their bounties
And beauty on his face: that eye was Iuno's,
Those lips were his that won the golden Ball,
That virgin-blush Diana's: here they meet,
As in a sacred Synod. My Lords, I must entreat
A while your wished forbearance.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We obey you Lady.

div2.stage: Exit Guido and Mizald. Ma. Rob.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p:
My Lord, with you I have some conference.
I pray my Lord, do you woo every Lady
In this phrase you do me?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Fairest, till now,
Love was an Infant in my Oratory.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And kiss thus too?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
I never was so kissed, leave thus to please,
Flames into flames, seas thou pourest into seas.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Pray frown my Lord, let me see how many wives
You will have. Heigh-ho, you will bury me I see.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: In the Swans down, and tomb thee in mine arms.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Then folks shall pray in vain to send me rest.
Away, you are such another meddling Lord.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
By heaven my love is as chaste as thou art fair,
And both exceed comparison: by this kiss,
That crowns me Monarch of another world
Superior to the first, fair, thou shalt see
As unto heaven, my love so unto thee.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Alas poor creatures, when we are once on the falling hand,
A man may easily come over us.
It is as hard for us to hide our love,
As to shut sin from the Creators eyes.
I'faith my Lord, I had a Month's mind unto you,
As tedious as a full riped Maidenhead.
And Count of Cypres, think my love as pure,
As the first opening of the blooms in May;
Your virtues man; nay, let me not blush to say so:
And see for your sake thus I leave to sorrow.
Begin this subtle conjuration with me,
And as this Taper, due unto the dead,
I here extinguish, so my late dead Lord
I put out ever from my memory,
That his remembrance may not wrong our love.
As bold-faced women when they wed another,
Banquet their husbands with their dead loves' heads.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
And as I sacrifice this to his Ghost,
With this expire all corrupt thoughts of youth,
That fame-insatiate Devil Jealousy,
And all the sparks that may bring unto flame,
Hate betwixt man and wife or breed defame.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Marry Amen, I say: Madam, are you that were in
for all day, now come to be in for all night? How now Count
Arsena?

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.p:
Faith Signior not unlike the condemned malefactor,
That hears his judgment openly pronounced;
But I ascribe to Fate, Joy swell your love,
Cypres, and Willow grace my drooping crest.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.p:
We do intend our Hymeneall rights
With the next rising Sun. Count Cypres,
Next to our Bride, the welcomest to our feast.

sp.speaker: Count. Ars.
sp.p:
Saneta Maria, what thinkst thou of this change?
A Players passion I will believe hereafter,
And in a Tragic Scene weep for old Priam,
When fell revenging Pirrhus with supposed
And artificial wounds mangles his breast,
And think it a more worthy act to me,
Than trust a female mourning ore her love:
Naught that is done of woman shall me please,
Natures step-children rather her desire.

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.p:
Learn of a well composed Epigram,
A woman's love, and thus it was sung unto us:
The Tapers that stood on her husbands hearse,
Isabell' advances to a second bed:
Is it not wondrous strange for to rehearse
She should so soon forget her husband dead;
One hour? for if the husbands life once fade,
Both love and husband in one grave are laid.
But we forget ourselves, I am for the marriage
Of Signior Claridiana, and the fine Mistress Abigall.

sp.speaker: Count. Ars.
sp.p: I for his arch-foes wedding Signior Rogero, and the spruce Mistress Thais: but see, the solemn rites are ended, and from their several Temples they are come.

sp.speaker: Mizal.
sp.p: A quarrel on my life.

div2.stage: Enter at one doore Signior Claridiana, Abigal his wife, the Lady Lentvlvs with Rosemary as from Church. At the other doore Signior Rogero and Thais his wife, Mendosa Foscarii, Nephew to the Duke, from the Bridall, they see one another, and draw, Count Arsena and others step betweene them.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Good my Lord detain me not, I will tilt at him.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
Remember, Sir, this is your wedding day,
And that triumph belongs only to your wife.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: If you be noble let me cut off his head.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Remember on the other side, you have a maiden-head of your own to cut off.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
I will make my marriage day like to the bloody bridal
Alcides by the fiery Centaurs had.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Husband, dear Husband!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Away with these caterwaulers.
Come on sir.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Thou son of a Jew.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Alas poor wench, thy husband is circumcised.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Begot when thy father's face was toward the East,
to show that thou wouldst prove a Caterpillar:
His Messias shall not save thee from me,
I will send thee to him in collops.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p: O fry not in choler so Sir.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p:
Mountebank with thy Pedantical action,
Rimatrix, Buglers, Rhimocers.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I conjure you
By the virtues of men.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Shall any broken Quack-salver's Bastard oppose him
to me in my Nuptials? No, but I will show him better metal
than ere the Gallimaufry his father used. Thou scum
of his melting pots, that wert christened in a Crusoile, with
Mercuries water, to show thou wouldst prove a stinging Aspis;
for all thou spittest is Aqua fortis, and thy breath is a compound
of poisons stillatory: if I get within thee, hadst thou
the scaly hyde of a Crocodile, as thou art partly of his nature,
I would leave thee as bare as an Anatomy at the second
viewing.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Thou Jew, of the Tribe of Gad, that sure, there
were none here but thou and I, wouldst teach me the Art
of breathing, thou wouldst run like a Dromedary.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Thou that art the tallest man of Christendom; when
thou art alone, if thou dost maintain this to my face, I will make thee skip like an Ounce.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Nay, good sir, be you still.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p:
Let the Quack-salver's son be still:
His father was still, and still, and still again.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: By the Almighty I will study Necromancy but I will be revenged.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, leave these dissentions,
Signior Rogero, you are a man of worth.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: True, all the City points at him for a Knave.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p:
You are of like reputation Signior Claridiana:
The hatred twixt your Grandsires first began,
Impute it to the folly of that age.
These your dissentions may erect a faction,
Like to the Capulets and Montagues.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Put it to equal arbitration, choose your friends,
The Senators will think them happy in it.

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.p: I will never embrace the smoke of a Furnace, the quintessence of mineral or simples, or as I may say more learnedly, nor the spirit of Quicksilver.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Nor I such a Centaur, half a man, half an Ass, and
all a Jew.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p:
Nay, then we will be Constables, and force a quiet:
Gentlemen, keep them asunder, and help to persuade them.

div2.stage: Exeunt all the Men. Manet Lent. Thais. Abig. and Mend.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Well Ladies, your Husbands behave them as lustily on
their wedding days, as ere I heard any. Nay Lady widow, you
and I must have a falling: you are of Signior Mizaldus faction,
and I am your vowed enemy, from the bodkin to the pincase.
Hark in your ear.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p:
Well Thais, O you are a cunning carver: we two that
any time these fourteen years have called sisters, brought and
bred up together: that have told one another all our wanton
dreams, talked all night-long of young men, and spent many an
idle hour, fasted upon the stones on Saint Agnes night together,
practised all the petulant amorousnesses that delights young
Maids, yet have you concealed not only the marriage, but
the man: and well you might deceive me, for I will be sworn
you never dreamed of him, and it stands against all reason you
should enjoy him you never dreamed of.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Is not all this the same in you? Did you ever manifest
your Sweethearts nose, that I might nose him by it? commended
his calf, or his nether-lip? apparent signs that you were
not in love or wisely covered it. Have you ever said, such a man
goes upright, or has a better gate than any of the rest, as indeed,
since he is proved a Magnifico, I thought thou wouldst have put
it into my hands what ere it had been.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Well wench, we have cross fates: our Husbands such
inveterate foes, and we such entire friends, but the best is we are
neighbours, and our back Arbours may afford visitation freely:
prithee let us maintain our familiarity still whatsoever thy husband
do unto thee, as I am afraid he will cross it in the nick.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Faith, you little one, If I please him in one thing, he
shall please me in all, that is certain. Who shall I have to keep
my counsel if I miss thee? who shall teach me to use the
bridle, when the reins are in mine own hand? what to long for?
when to take Physic? where to be melancholy? why, we two
are one another's grounds, without which would be no Music.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Well said wench, and the Pricksong we use shall be
our husbands.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: I will long for Swines-flesh on the first child.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Wilt thou little Jew? And I to kiss thy husband
Upon the least bellyache. This will mad them.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
I kiss thee wench for that, and with it confirm our
friendship.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: By these sweet lips Widow.

sp.speaker: Lady Lent.
sp.p:
Good my Lord learn to swear by rote:
Your birth and fortune makes my brain suppose,
That like a man heated with wines and lust,
She that is next your object is your mate,
Till the soul water have quenched out the fire.
You the Dukes kinsman, tell me, I am young,
Fair, rich, and virtuous; I myself will flatter
Myself, till you are gone, that are more fair,
More rich, more virtuous, and more debonair:
All which are ladders to an higher reach:
Who drinks a puddle that may taste a spring?
Who kiss a Subject that may hug a King?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Yes, the Camel always drinks in puddle water,
And as for judging read Antiquities.
Faith, Madam, I will board thee one of these days.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Aye, but never bed me my Lord: my vow is firm
Since God hath called me to this noble state,
Much to my grief, of virtuous Widow-hood,
No man shall ever come within my gates.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Wilt thou ram up thy porch-hold? O widow, I perceive
You are ignorant of the Lover's legerdemain.
There is a fellow that by Magic will assist
To murther Princes invisible, I can command his spirit.
Or what say you to a fine scaling Ladder of ropes?
I can tell you, I am a mad wag-halter:
But by the vertue I see seated in you,
And by the worthy fame is blazoned of you,
By little Cupid, that is mighty named,
And can command my looser follies down,
I love, and must enjoy, yet with such limits,
As one that knows enforced marriage
To be the Furies sister. Think of me.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: How now Lady, does the toy take you, as they say?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
No, my Lord, nor do we take your toy, as they say.
This is a childes birth, that must not be delivered before a man,
Though your Lordship might be a Mid-wife for your chin.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Some bawdy riddle is it not? you long till it be night.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
No, my Lord, women's longing comes after their marriage
night. Sister, see you be constant now.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Why, dost think I will make my Husband a Cuckold?
O here they come.

div2.stage: Enter at seuerall doores Count Ars. with Claridiana: Gvido, with Rogero, at another doore, Mendosa meetes them.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Signior Rogero, are you yet qualified?

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
Yes: does any man think I will go like a sheep to the
slaughter? Hands off my Lord, your Lordship may chance come
under my hands: If you do, I shall show myself a Citizen, and revenge basely.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
I think if I were receiving the holy Sacrament
His sight would make me gnash my teeth terribly:
But there is the beauty without parallel,
In whom the Graces and the Virtues meet:
In her aspect mild Honour sits and smiles:
And who looks there, were it the savage Bear,
But would derive new nature from her eyes.
But to be reconciled simply for him,
Were mankind to be lost again I would let it,
And a new heap of stones should stock the world.
In heaven and earth this power beauty hath,
It inflames Temperance, and temperates Wrath:
What ere thou art, mine art thou wise or chaste:
I shall set hard upon thy marriage vow,
And write revenge high in thy Husbands brow,
In a strange Character. You may begin sir.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Signior Claridiana, I hope Signior Rogero
Thus employed me about a good office,
It were worthy Cicerces tongue, a famous Oration now?
But friendship that is mutually embraced of the Gods,
And is Jove's Usher to each sacred Sinod,
Without the which he could not reign in heaven,
That over-goes my admiration shall not undergo my censure.
These hot flames of rage, that else will be
As fire midst your nuptial Jollity,
Burning the edge off from the present Joy,
And keep you wake to terror.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
I have not yet swallowed the Rhimatrix nor the Onocentaure,
the Rimocheros was monstrous.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p:
Sir, be you of the more flexible nature, and confess
an error.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
I must, the Gods of love command,
And that bright Star, her eye, that guides my fate. Signior Rogero, joy then Signior Rogero.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Signior, sir, O Devil.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Good Husband show yourself a temperate man,
Your mother was a woman I dare swear;
No Tiger got you, nor no Bear was rival
In your conception: you seem like the issue
The Painters limb leaping from Envy's mouth,
That devours all he meets.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Had the last, or the least Syllable
Of this more than immortal eloquence,
Commenced to me when rage had been so high
Within my blood, that it over-topped my soul,
Like to the Lion when he hears the sound
Of Dian's Bowstring in some shady wood,
I should have couched my lowly limb on earth,
And held my silence a proud sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Slave, I will fight with thee at any odds,
Or name an instrument fit for destruction,
That never was made to make away a man,
I will meet thee on the ridges of the Alps,
Or some inhospitable wilderness,
Stark naked, at push-of-pike, or keen Curtle-axe,
At Turkish Sickle, Babylonian Saw,
The ancient Hooks of great Cadwalleder,
Or any other heathen invention.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: O God bless the man.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Counsel him good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Our tongues are weary, and he desperate,
He does refuse to hear: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
I am not mad, I can hear, I can see, I can feel,
But a wise rage in man, wrongs past compare,
Should be well nourished as his virtues are:
I would have it known unto each valiant spirit.
He wrongs no man that to himself does right.
Catzo I have done, Signior Rogero, I have done.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p:
By heaven this voluntary reconciliation made
Freely, and of itself, argues unfeigned
And virtuous knot of love. So sirs embrace.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Sir, by the conscience of a Catholic man,
And by our mother Church that binds
And doth atone in amity with God,
The souls of men, that they with men be one,
I tread into the centre all the thoughts
Of ill in me, toward you, and memory
Of what from you might ought disparage me,
Wishing unfeignedly it may sink low,
And as untimely births want power to grow.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Christianly said: Signior what would you have more?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And so I swear, you are honest Onocentaure.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p:
Nay see now, fie upon your turbulent spirit,
Did he do it in this form?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
If you think not this sufficient, you shall command
me to be reconciled in another form, as a Rhimatrix or a Rimocheros.

sp.speaker: Mind.
sp.p: 'sblood, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Well, give me your hands first, I am friends with you
i'faith: thereupon I embrace you, kiss your Wife, and God give
us joy.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: You mean me and my husband.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You take the meaning better than the speech, Lady.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p:
The like wish I, but never can be the like,
And therefore wish I thee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: By this bright light that is derived from thee.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: So sir, you make me a very light creature.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
But that thou art a blessed Angel, sent
Down from the Gods to attone mortal men,
I would have thought deeds beyond all men's thoughts,
And executed more upon his corps:
O let him thank the beauty of this eye,
And not his resolute sword or destiny.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p:
What sayst thou Mizaldus, come applaud this Jubilee,
A day these hundred years before not truly known,
To these divided factions.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
No nor this day had it been falsely borne,
But that I mean to sound it with his horn.

sp.speaker: Miz.
sp.p:
I liked the former jar better: than they showed like
men and Soldiers; now like Cowards and Lechers.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p:
Well said Mizaldus: thou art like the Base Viol in a
Consort, let the other Instrument wish and delight in your highest
sense, thou art still grumbling.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Nay, sweet receive it,
And in it my heart:
And when thou readest a moving syllable
Think that my soul was Secretary to it.
It is your love, and not the odious wish
Of my revenge, in stiling him a Cuckold,
Makes me presume thus far: then read it fair,
My passion is ample as your beauties are.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Well sir, we will not stick with you.

sp.speaker: Arsena.
sp.p:
And Gentlemen, since it hath happed so fortunately,
I do entreat we may all meet tomorrow,
In some Heroic Masque, to grace the Nuptials
Of the most noble Countess of Sweuia.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Who does the young Count marry?

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p:
O sir, who but the very heir of all her sex,
That beares the Palm of beauty from them all:
Others compared to her, show like faint Stars
To the full Moon of wonder in her face:
The Lady Isabella, the late Widow
To the deceased and noble Viscount Hermus.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Law you there, widow, there is one of the last edition,
Whose Husband yet retains in his cold trunk
Some little airing of his noble guest,
Yet she a fresh Bride as the month of May.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
Well my Lord, I am none of these,
That have my second Husband bespoke,
My door shall be a testimony of it.
And but these noble Marriages incite me,
My much abstracted presence should have showed it.
If you come to me, hark in your ear my Lord,
Look your Ladder of ropes be strong,
For I shall tie you to your Tackling.

sp.speaker: Arsen.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your answer to the Masque.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Your Honour leads, we will follow.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: Signior Claridiana.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: I attend you sir.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p: You will be constant.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Above the Adamant the Goat's blood shall not break me,
Yet shallow fools, and plainer moral men,
That understand not what they undertake,
Fall in their own snares, or come short of vengeance,
No, let the Sun view with an open face,
And afterward shrink in his blushing cheeks,
Ashamed, and cursing of the fixed decree,
That makes his light bawd to the crimes of men,
When I have ended what I now devise.
Appolloes Oracle shall swear me wise,
Strumpet his wife, branch my false-seeming friend,
And make him foster what my hate begot,
A bastard, that when age and sickness seize him,
Shall be a corrosive to his griping heart:
I will write to her, for what her modesty
Will not permit, nor my adulterate forcing,
That blushless Herald shall not fear to tell:
Rogero shall know yet that his foe is a man,
And what is more, a true Italian.

div2.stage: Enter Roberto, Lord Cardinall, Isabella, LadyLentvlvs, Abigal and Thais. Lights.

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.p:
My grave Lord Cardinal, we congratulate,
And zealously do entertain your love:
That from your high and divine contemplation,
You have vouchsafed to consummate a day
Due to our Nuptials: O, may this knot you knit,
This individual Gordiant grasp of hands,
In sight of God so fairly intermixed,
Never be severed, as heaven smiles at it,
By all the Darts shot by infernal Jove,
Angels of grace Amen, Amen, say to it.
Fair Lady Widow, and my worthy Mistress,
Do you keep silence for a wager?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Do you ask a woman that question my Lord,
When she enforcedly pursues what she is forbidden?
I think if I had been tied to silence,
I should have been worthy the Cucking-stool ere this time.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
You shall not be my Orator (Lady) that pleads thus
for yourself.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord, the Masquers are at hand.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Give them kind entertainment. Some worthy friends
of mine, my Lord, unknown to me, too lavish of their loves,
Bring their own welcome in a solemn Masque.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p:
I am glad there is Noble-men in the Masque
With our Husbands to over-rule them,
They had shamed us all else.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Why? for why, I pray?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p:
Why? marry they had come in with some City show else,
Hired a few Tinsel coats at the Vizard-makers, which would
have made them look, for all world, like Bakers in their linen
bases, and mealy vizards, new come from bolting. I saw a show
once at the Marriage of a Magnificero's daughter, presented by
Time: which Time was an old bald thing; a servant, it was the
best man; he was a Dyer, and came in likeness of the Rainbow
in all manner of colours, to show his Art, but the Rainbow
smelt of urine, so we were all afraid the property was changed,
and looked for a shower. Then came in after him, one that (it
seemed) feared no colours, a Grocer that had trimmed up himself
handsomely: he was Justice, and showed reasons why. And I
think this Grocer, I mean this Justice, had borrowed a weather-beaten
Balance from some Justice of a Conduit, both which
Scales were replenished with the choice of his Ware,
And the more liberally to show his nature,
He gave every woman in the room her handful.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
O great act of Justice! well, and my Husband come
cleanly off with this, he shall never betray his weakness more,
but confess himself a Citizen hereafter, and acknowledge their
wit, for alas they come short.

div2.stage: Enter in the Masque, the Count of Arsena, Mendosa, Claridiana, Torch-bearers. They deliuer the shields to their seuerall Mistresses, that is to say, Mendosa, to the Lady Lentvlvs; Claridiana, to Abigal; to Isabella, Gvido Count of Arsena; to Thais, Rogero.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Good my Lord, be my expositor.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p:
The Sun setting, a man pointing at it:
The Motto, Senso tamen ipse Calarem:
Fair Bride, some servant of yours, that here imitates
To have felt the heat of Love bred in your brightness,
But setting thus from him, by marriage,
He only here acknowledgeth your power,
And must expect beams of a morrow Sun.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Lord Bridegroom, will you interpret me?

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.p:
A sable Shield: the word, Vidua spes.
What the forlorn hope, in black, despairing?
Lady Lentulus, is this the badge of all your Suitors?

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Aye by my troth my Lord, if they come to me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
I could give it another interpretation. Methinks this
Lover has learned, of women, to deal by contraries: if so, then
here he says, the Widow is his only hope.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: No: good my Lord, let the first stand.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.p: Inquire of him, and he will resolve the doubt.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
What is here? a Ship sailing nigh her haven?
With good ware belike: it is well ballast.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
O, your this device smells of the Merchant. What is
your ships name, I pray? The forlorn Hope?

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p: No: The Merchant Royal.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: And why not Adventurer?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
You see no likelihood of that: would it not fain be
in the haven? The word, Vt tangerem Portum.
Marry, for ought I know, God grant it. What is there?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Mine is an Azure shield: marry what else; I should
tell thee more than I understand; but the word is,
Aut precio, aut precibus.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, some Common-counsel device.

div2.stage: They take the women, and dance the first change.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Fair widow, how like you this change?

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: I changed too lately to like any.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
O your husband! you wear his memory like a Deaths-head.
For heaven's love think of me as of the man
Whose dancing days you see are not yet done.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Yet you sink apace sir.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: The fault is in my Upholsterer, Lady.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p:
Thou shalt as soon find Truth telling a lie,
Vertue a Bawd, Honesty a Courtier,
As me turned recreant to thy least design:
Love makes me speak, and he makes love divine.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Would Love could make you so: but it is his guise
To let us surfeit ere he ope our eyes.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: You grasp my hand too hard i'faith, fair sir,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Not as you grasp my hart, unwilling wanton.
Were but my breast bare and Anatomized,
Thou shouldst behold there how thou torturest it:
And as Appelles limbed the Queen of Love,
In her right hand grasping a heart in flames,
So may I thee, fairer, but crueler.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Well sir, your visor gives you colour for what you say.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Grace me to wear this favour, it is a Gem
That veils to your eyes, though not to the Eagles,
And in exchange give me one word of comfort.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Aye marry: I like this wooer well:
He will win his pleasure out of the stones.

div2.stage: The second change.Isabella fals in loue with Rogero when the changers speak.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p:
Change is no robbery: yet in this change
Thou robbest me of my hart, sure Cupid is here,
Disguised like a pretty Torch-bearer,
And makes his brand a Torch, that with more sleight
He may entrap weak women: here the sparks
Fly as in Etna from his Father's Anvil.
O powerful Boy! my heart is on fire, and unto mine eyes
The raging flames ascend, like to two Beacons,
Summoning my strongest powers, but all too late,
The Conqueror already opes the gate.
I will not ask his name.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: You dare put it into my hands.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Zounds, do you think I will not?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Then thus, tomorrow (you will be secret, servant.)

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: All that I do, I will do in secret.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: My husband goes to Mawrano to renew the Farm he has.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Well, what time goes the Jakes-farmer?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
He shall not be long out, but you shall put in, I warrant
you. Have a care that you stand just in the nick about six a
clock in the evening; my Maid shall conduct you up, to save
mine honour you must come up drizzling, and to avoid suspicion.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Zounds, hoodwinked, and if you will open all sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: But if you fail to do it.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: The Sun shall fail the day first.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Tie this ring fast, you may be sure to know.
You will brag of this, now you have brought me to the bay.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Pox on this Masque: would it were done, I might
To my Apothecaries for some stirring meats.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p:
Methinks sir, you should blush even through your visor,
I have scarce patience to dance out the rest.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p:
The worse my fate that ploughs a marble quarry:
Primaleon yet thy Image was more kind,
Although thy love not half so true as mine.
Dance they that list, I sail against the wind.

sp.speaker: Thais.
Guid.
sp.p:
The Spheres never danced unto a better tune.
Sound Music there.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: It was Music that he spake.

div2.stage: The third change ended, Ladies fall off.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Gallants I thank you, and
Begin a health to your Mistresses.

sp.speaker: 3. or 4.
sp.p: Fair thanks sir Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
He speaks not to this pledge, has he no Mistress?
Would I might chose one for him: but it may be
He doth adore a brighter Star than we.

div2.stage: Rogero dances a Laualto, or a Galliard, & in the midst of it, falleth into the Brides lap, but straight leapes vp, and danceth it out.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sit Ladies sit, you have had standing long.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Bless the man: sprightly and nobly done.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: What, is your Ladyship hurt?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
O no, an easy fall.
Was I not deep enough, thou God of lust,
But I must further wade? I am his now,
As sure as Iuno's Jove's, Hymen take flight,
And see not me, it is not my wedding night.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: The Brides departed, discontent it seems.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: We will after her. Gallants, unmask I pray, And taste a homely banquet we entreat.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Candidi Ernigos I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Come Widow, I will be bold to put you in.
My Lord will you have a sociate?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Good gentlemen if I have any interest in you,
Let me depart unknown, it is a disgrace
Of an eternal memory.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
What the fall my Lord, as common a thing as can be,
the stiffest man in Italy may fall between a woman's legs.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Would I had changed places with you my Lord, would
it had been my hap.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
What Cuckold laid his horns in my way?
Signior Claridiana, you were by the Lady when I fell,
Do you think I hurt her?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You could not her, my Lord, between the legs.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: What was it I fell withal?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: A cross point my Lord.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Cross point indeed: well if you love me, let me hence unknown,
The silence yours, the disgrace mine own.

div2.stage: Enter Isabella with a gilt Goblet and meetes Rogero.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Sir, if Wine were Nectar I will begin a health,
To her that were most gracious in your eye,
Yet deign, as simply it is the gift of Bacchus,
To give her pledge that drinks: this God of Wine
Cannot inflame me more to appetite,
Though he be co-supreme with mighty Love,
Than thy fair shape.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Zounds she comes to deride me.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
That kiss shall serve
To be a pledge although my lips should starve.
No trick to get that visor from his face?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I will steal hence, and so conceal disgrace.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Sir, have you left naught behind?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Yes, Lady but the Fates will not permit
(As Gems once lost are seldom or never found)
I should convey it with me. Sweet Good-night.
She bends to me: there is my fall again.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
He is gone, that lightning that a while doth strike
Our eyes with amazed brightness, and on a sudden
Leaves us in prisoned darkness. Lust thou art hie,
My smiles may well come from the Sky.
Anna, Anna.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Madam, did you call?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Follow yond stranger, prithee learn his name:
We may hereafter thank him. How I dote?
Is he not a God
That can command what other men would win
With the hardest advantage? I must have him,
Or shadow-like follow his fleeting steps.
Were I as Daphne, and he followed chase,
Though I rejected young Appolloes love,
And like a Dream beguile his wandering steps,
Should he pursue me through the neighbouring grove,
Each Cowslip stalk should trip a willing fall,
Till he were mine, who till then am his thrall:
Nor will I blush, since worthy is my chance.
It is said that Venus with a Satyre slept,
And how much short came she of my fair aim?
Then Queen of Love a president I will be,
To teach fair women learn to love of me.
Speak Music, what is his name.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Madam, It was the worthy Count Massino.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Blest be thy tongue: the worthy Count indeed,
The worthiest of the Worthies. Trusty Anna,
Hast thou packed up those Monies, Plate, and Jewels
I gave direction for?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p:
Yes, Madam, I have trust up them, that many
A proper man has been trust up for.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I thank thee, take the wings of night,
Beloved Secretary, and post with them to Sweuia,
There furnish up some stately Palace
Worthy to entertain the King of Love:
Prepare it for my coming and my Loves,
Ere Phoebus Steeds once more unharnessed be,
Or ere he sport with his beloved Thetis,
The silver-footed Goddess of the Sea,
We will set forward. Fly like the Northern wind,
Or swifter, Anna, fleete like to my mind.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I am just of your mind Madam, I am gone.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
So to the house of Death the mourner goes,
That is bereft of what his soul desired,
As I to bed, I to my nuptial bed,
The heaven on earth: so to thought slaughters went
The pale Andromeda bedewed with tears,
When every minute she expected gripes of a fell monster,
And in vain bewailed the act of her creation.
Sullen Night that lookest with sunk eyes on my nuptial bed,
With never a Star that smiles upon the end,
Mend thy slack pace, and lend the malcontent,
The hoping lover, and the wishing Bride
Beams that too long thou shadowest: or if not
In spite of thy fixed front when my loathed Mate
Shall struggle in due pleasure for his right,
I will think it my love, and die in that delight.

div2.stage: Enter at seuerall doores Abigal and Thais.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Thais, you are an early riser.
I have that to show will make your hair stand an-end.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Well Lady, and I have that to show you will bring your
courage down. What would you say, and I would name a party
saw your Husband court, kiss, nay almost go through for the hole?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
How, how, what would I say? nay, by this light, what
would I not do? If ever Amazon fought better, or more at the
face than I will do, let me never be thought a new married wife.
Come unmask her: it is some admirable creature, whose beauty
you need not paint. I warrant you, it is done to your hand.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Would any woman but I, be abused to her face?
Prithee read the contents: Knowest thou the Character?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
It is my Husbands hand, and a love-letter:
But for the contents I find none in it. Has the lustful monster,
All back and belly-starved me thus? What defect does he see in
me? I will be sworn wench, I am of as pliant and yielding body
to him, even which way he will, he may turn me as he list
himself. What? and dedicate to thee: Aye marry, here is a style so
high, as a man cannot help a Dog over it. He was wont to write
to me in the City phrase, My good Abigall: here is Astonishment
of nature, unparalleled excellency, and most unequal rarity of creation:
Three such words will turn any honest woman in the world
whore: for a woman is never won till she know not what
to answer; and beshrew me if I understand any of these: you
are the party I perceive, and here is a white sheet, that your husband
has promised me to do penance in: you must not think to
dance the shaking of the sheets alone though there be not such
rare phrases in it, it is more to the matter; a legible hand, but for
the dash, or the (he) and (as): short bawdy Parenthesis as ever
you saw, to the purpose: he has not left out a prick I warrant
you, wherein he has promised to do me any good, but the Law is
in mine own hand.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
I ever thought by his red beard he would prove a
Iudas, here am I bought and sold; he makes much of me indeed.
Well wench, we were best wisely in time seek for prevention,
I should be loath to take drink and die of it, as I am afraid
I shall that he will lie with thee.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
To be short sweet hart, I will be true to thee, though a
liar to my Husband: I have signed your Husbands bill like a
Woodcock as he is held, persuaded him (since naught but
my love can assuage his violent passions) he should enjoy, like
a private friend, the pleasures of my bed: I told him my Husband
was to go to Mawrano today to renew a Farm he has,
and in the mean time he might be tenant at will, to use mine:
this false fire has so took with him, that he is ravished afore he
come. I have had stones on him all red: dost know this:

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Aye, too well, it blushes for his Master.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p:
Now my Husband will be hawking about thee anon,
And thou canst meet him closely.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
By my faith I would be loath in the dark, if he
knew me.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
I mean thus: the same occasion will serve him too,
they are birds of a feather, and will fly together, I warrant
thee wench, appoint him to come: say that thy Husband is gone
for Mawrano, and tell me anon if thou madest not his heart-blood
spring, for joy, in his face.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: I conceive you not all this while.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Then thou art a barren woman, and no marvel if thy
Husband love thee not: the hour for both to come is six, a
dark time fit for purblind lovers; and with cleanly conveyance
by the nigglers our maids, they shall be translated into our Bed-chambers.
Your Husband into mine, and mine into yours.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: But you mean they shall come in at the backdoors.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Who, our Husbands? nay, and they come not in at the
fore-doors, there will be no pleasure in it. But we two will climb over our
garden-Pales, and come in that way, (the chastest that
are in Venice will stray for a good turn) and thus wittily will
we be bestowed, you into my house to your husband, and I
into your house to my husband, and I warrant thee before a
month come to an end, they will crack louder of this nights-lodging, than the Bed-steads.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: All is if our Maids keep secret.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Mine is a Maid I will be sworn, she has kept her secrets hitherto.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Troth, and I never had any Sea-captain boarded in
my house.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Go to then: and the better to avoid suspicion,
Thus we must insist, they must come up drizzling, recreate
themselves with their delight an hour or two, and after a million
of kisses, or so.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: But is my husband content to come drizzling?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
What not to save mine honour? he that will run
through fire, as he has professed, will by the heat of his love,
grope in the dark. I warrant him he shall save mine honour.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: I am afraid my voice will discover me.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Why then, you are best say nothing, and take it thus
quietly when your husband comes.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Aye, but you know a woman cannot choose but speak
in these cases.

sp.speaker: Abig.
Thais.
sp.p: Farewell wise-woman.

sp.speaker: Mizal.
sp.p:
Now gins my vengeance mount high in my lust:
It is a rare creature, she will do it i'faith;
And I am armed at all points. A rare whiblin,
To be revenged, and yet gain pleasure in it,
One height above revenge: yet what a slave am I,
Are there not younger Brothers enough, but we must
Branch one another? O but mine is revenge,
And who on that does dream
Must be a Tyrant ever in extreme.
O my Wife Thais get my Breakfast ready,
I must into the Country to a Farm I have
Some two miles off, and, as I think,
Shall not come home tonight. Iaques, Iaques,
Get my Vessel ready to row me down the River.
Prithee make haste Sweet girl.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
So, there is one fool shipped away: are your cross points
discovered? Get your Breakfast ready!
By this light I will tie you to hard fare:
I have been too sparing of that you prodigally offer
Voluntary to another: well you shall be a tame fool hereafter.
The finest light is when we first defraud;
Husband tonight it is I must lie abroad.

div2.stage: Enter Isabella and a Page with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Here, take this Letter, bear it to the Count:
But Boy, first tell me; thinkst thou I am in love?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Madam, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Canst thou not tell? Dost thou not see my face?
Is not the face the Index of the mind?
And canst thou not distinguish Love by that?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Then take this Letter and deliver it
Unto the worthy Count. No, fie upon him,
Come back again: tell me, why shouldst thou think
That same is a Love-letter?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I do not think so Madam.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I know thou dost: for thou dost ever use
To hold the wrong opinion. Tell me true,
Dost thou not think that Letter is of Love?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: If you would have me think so Madam, yes.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
What dost thou think thy Lady is so fond?
Give me the Letter, thyself shall see it.
Yet I should tear it in the breaking ope,
And make him lay a wrongful charge on thee;
And say thou brokest it open by the way;
And saw what heinous things I charge him with:
But it is all one, the Letter is not of love,
Therefore deliver it unto himself,
And tell him he is deceived, I do not love him.
But if he think so bid him come to me,
And I will confute him straight; I will show him reasons,
I will show him plainly why I cannot love him.
And if he hap to read it in thy hearing,
Or chance to tell thee that the words were sweet,
Do not thou then disclose my lewd intent,
Under those Syren words, and how I mean
To use him when I have him at my will:
For then thou wilt destroy the plot that is laid,
And make him fear to yield when I do wish
Only to have him yield; for when I have him,
None but myself shall know how I will use him.
Be gone, why stayest thou? yet return again.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Aye Madam.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Why dost thou come again? I bad thee go.
If I say, Go, never return again.
My blood, like to a troubled Ocean,
Cuffed with the Winds, incertain where to rest,
Buts at the utmost share of every limb.
My Husband is not the man I would have had:
O my new thoughts to this brave sprightly Lord,
Was fixed to that hid fire Lovers feel:
Where was my mind before, that refined judgment,
That represents rare objects to our passions?
Or did my lust beguile me of my sense?
Making me feast upon such dangerous cates,
For present want, that needs must breed a surfeit:
How was I shipwrecked? yet Isabella think
Thy Husband is a noble Gentleman, young, wise,
And rich: think what Fate follows thee,
And naught but lust doth blind thy worthy love:
I will desist. O no, it may not be.
Even as a head-strong Courser beares away
His Rider, vainly striving him to stay.
Or as a sudden gale thrusts into Sea
The Haven-touching Bark, now near the lea:
So wavering Cupid brings me back again,
And purple Love resumes his Darts again:
Here of themselves, thy shafts come as if shot:
Better than I thy quiver knows them not

div2.stage: Enter Count Arsena, and a Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Madam: the Count.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
So fell the Trojan wanderer on the Greek,
And bore away his ravished prize to Troy:
For such a beauty, brighter than his Dana.
Jove should (methinks) now come himself again:
Lovely Isabella, I confess me mortal:
Not worthy to serve thee in thought, I swear,
Yet shall not this same over-flow of favour
Diminish my vowed duty to your beauty.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Your love, my Lord, I blushingly proclaim it,
Hath power to draw me through a wilderness,
Were it armed with Furies, as with furious Beasts.
Boy, bid our Train be ready, we will to horse.
My Lord, I should say something, but I blush,
Courting is not befitting to our sex.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
I will teach you how to woo,
Say you have loved me long,
And tell me that a woman's feeble tongue
Was never tuned unto a wooing-string;
Yet for my sake you will forget your sex,
And court my Love with strained Immodesty,
Then bid me make you happy with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p:
Sir, though women do not woo, yet for your sake,
I am content to leave that civil custom,
And pray you kiss me.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Now use some unexpected ambages,
To draw me further into Vulcan's Net.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You love not me so well as I love you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Fair Lady, but I do.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Then show your love.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Why in this kiss I show it, and in my vowed service,
This wooing shall suffice, it is easier far
To make the current of a silver-brook
Convert his flowing backward to his Spring,
Than turn a woman wooer. There is no cause
Can turn the settled course of Natures Laws.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: My Lord, will you pursue the plot?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
The Letter gives direction here for Pauie.
To horse, to horse: thus once Eridace,
With looks regardant, did the Thracian gaze,
And lost his gift, while he desired the sight.
But wiser I, lead by more powerful charm;
I would see the world win thee from out mine arm.

div2.stage: Enter at seuerall doores, Claridiana and Gvido.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: Zounds, is the Huritano coming? Claridiana what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
The Countess of Sweuia has new taken horse.
Fly Phoebus, fly, the hour is six a clock.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Whither is she going Signior?

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Even as Jove went to meet his simile.
To the Devil I think.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p: You know not wherefore?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
To say sooth I do not.
So in immortal wise shall I arrive.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: At the Gallows. What in a passion Signior?

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Zounds, do not hold me sir:
Beauteous Thais, I am all thine wholly.
The staff is now advancing for the Rest,
And when I tilt, Mizaldus aware thy Crest.

div2.stage: Enter Roberto, in his Night-gowne, and Cap, with Seruants, hee kneeles downe.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: What is here? the capering Cods-head tilting in the air?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
The Gods send her no Horse, a poor old age.
Eternal woe, and sickness lasting rage.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: My Lord, you may yet over-take them.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Furies supply that place, for I will not: no,
She that can forsake me when pleasure is in the full,
Fresh and untired, what would she on the least barren coldness?
I warrant you she has already got
Her Bravos, and her Ruffians: the meanest whore
Will have one buckler, but your great ones more.
The shores of Sicily retains not such a Monster,
Though to Galley-slaves they daily prostitute.
To let the Nuptial Tapers give light to her new lust,
Who would have thought it?
She that could no more forsake my company,
Than can the day forsake the glorious presence of the Sun.
When I was absent, then her galled eyes
Would have shed April showers, and out-wept
The clouds in that same over-passionate mood:
When they drowned all the world, yet now forsakes me:
Women your eyes shed glances like the Sun:
Now shines your brightness, now your light is done.
On the sweetest Flowers you shine, it is but by chance,
And on the basest Weed you will waste a glance.
Your beams once lost can never more be found:
Unless we wait until your course run round,
(And take you at fist hand.) Since I cannot
Enjoy the noble title of a man,
But after-ages, as our virtues are
Buried whilst we are living, will sound out
My infamy, and her degenerate shame;
Yet in my life I will smother it if I may,
And, like a dead man, to the world bequeath
These houses of vanity, Mils, and Lands.
Take what you will, I will not keep among you Servants,
And welcome some religious Monastery,
A true sworn Beads-man I will hereafter be,
And wake the morning cock with holy prayers.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Good my Lord: noble Master.

sp.speaker: Rob.
Guid.
sp.p:
This is conversion, is it not? as good as might have been,
He turns religious upon his Wives turning Courtesan.
This is just like some of our gallant Prodigals,
When they have consumed their Patrimonies wrongfully,
They turn Capuchins for devotion,

div2.stage: Claridiana, and Rogero being in a readinesse, are receiued in at one anothers houses by their Maids.
Then Enter Mendosa, with a Page, to the Lady Lentvlvs Window.

sp.speaker: Mendosa.
sp.p:
Night like a solemn Mourner frowns on earth,
Envying that Day should force her doff her robes,
Or Phoebus chase away her Melancholy.
Heaven's eyes look faintly through her sable masque,
And silver Cinthia hies her in her Sphere,
Scorning to grace black nights solemnity.
Be unpropitious Night to villain thoughts,
But let thy Diamonds shine on virtuous love:
This is the lower house of high-built heaven,
Where my chaste Phaebe sits, enthroned among thoughts
So purely good, brings her to heaven on earth.
Such power hath souls in contemplation.
Sing boy (though night yet) like the mornings Lark:
A soul that is clear is light, though heaven be dark.

div2.stage: The Lady Lentvlvs, at her window.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Who speaks in Music to us?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Sweet, it is I. Boy, leave me, and to bed.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: I thank you for your Music: now good-night.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Leave not the World yet, Queen of Chastity,
Keep promise with thy Love Endimion,
And let me meet thee there on Latmus top.
It is I whose virtuous hopes are firmly fixed
On the fruition of thy chaste vowed love.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
My Lord, your honour made me promise your ascent into
my house, since my vow barred my doors,
By some wits engine, made for theft and lust:
Yet for your Honour, and my humble fame,
Check your blood's passions, and return dear Lord:
Suspicion is a Dog that still doth bite.
Without a cause, this act gives food to Envy;
Swollen big, it bursts, and poisons our clear flames.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Envy is stingless when she looks on thee.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Envy is blind, my Lord, and cannot see.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: If you break promise, fair, you break my hart.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
Then come. Yet stay. Ascend. Yet let us part.
I fear, yet know not what I fear:
Your Love is precious, yet mine Honour is dear.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
If I do stain thy Honour with foul lust,
May Thunder strike me, to show Jove is just.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
Then come my Lord, on earth your vow is given.
This aid I will lend you.

div2.stage: He throwes vp a ladder of cords, which she makes fast to some part the window, he asends, and at top fals.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
Thus I mount my heaven.
Receive me sweet.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
O me unhappy wretch.
How fares your Honour? speak Fate-crossed Lord.
If life retain his seat within you, speak;
Else like that Sestian Dame, that saw her Love,
Cast by the frowning billows, on the sands,
And lean death swollen big with the Hellespont,
In bleak Leander's body, like his Love,
Come I to thee, one grave shall serve us both.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Stay miracle of women, yet I breathe,
Though death be entered in this Tower of flesh,
He is not conqueror, my heart stands out,
And yields to thee, scorning his tyranny.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
My doors are vowed shut, and I cannot help you.
Your wounds are mortal, wounded is mine Honour,
If there the Town-guard find you. Unhappy Dame,
Relief is perjured, my vow kept, shame.
What hellish Destiny did twist my fate?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Rest seize thine eye-lids; be not passionate:
Sweet sleep secure, I will remove myself.
That Viper Envy shall not spot thy fame:
I will take that poison with me, my soul's rest,
For like a Serpent, I will creep on my breast.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
Thou more than man, love-wounded: joy and grief
fight in my blood. Thy wounds and constancy
Are both so strong none can have victory.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Darken the world, earth's-Queen, get thee to bed;
The earth is light while those two Stars are spread:
Their splendour will betray me to men's eyes.
Veil thy bright face: for if thou longer stay,
Phoebus will rise to thee, and make night day.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: To part and leave you hurt my soul doth fear.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: To part from hence I cannot, you being there.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p:
We will move together, then Fate Love controls,
And as we part so bodies part from souls.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Mine is the earth, thine the refined fire:
I am mortal, thou divine, then soul mount higher.

sp.speaker: Lent.
sp.p: Why then take comfort sweet, I will see you tomorrow.

div2.stage: He staggars on, and then fals downe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
My wounds are nothing, thy loss breeds my sorrow.
See now it is dark.
Support your Master, legs, a little further:
Faint not bold heart with anguish of my wound:
Try further yet, can blood weigh down my soul?
Desire is vain without ability.
Thus falls a Monarch, if Fate push at him.

div2.stage: Enter a Captaine and the Watch.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Come on my hearts, we are the Cities security, I will give
you your charge, and then like Courtiers every man spy out:
let no man in my company be afraid to speak to a Cloak lined
with Velvet, nor tremble at the sound of a jingling Spur.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p:
May I never be counted a cock of the game, if I fear
Spurs: but be gelded like a Capon for the preserving of my
voice.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
I will have none of my Band refrain to search a venereal
house, though his Wifes sister be a lodger there: nor take two
shillings of the Bawd to save the Gentlemen's credits that are
aloft: and so like voluntary Panders leave them, to the shame of
all Halberdiers.
Nay, for the Wenches, we will tickle them, that is flat.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
If you meet a Sheuoiliero, that is in the gross phrase, a
Knight, that swaggers in the street, and being taken, has no money
in his Purse to pay for his fees; it shall be a part of your duty
to entreat me to let him go.
O marvelous! is there such Sheuoiliers?
Some two hundred that is the least, that are revealed.

div2.stage: Enter the Watch, with Claridiana and Rogero taken in one anothers houses, in their shirts and night-gownes, they see one another.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
What groan is that? bring a light. Who lies there?
It is the Lord Mendosa, kinsman to our Duke.
Speak good my Lord, relate your dire mischance:
Life like a fearful servant flies his Master,
Art must atone them, or the whole man is lost.
Convey him to a Surgeons, then return:
No place shall be unsearched until we find
The truth of this mischance. Make haste again.
Whose house is this stands open? in, and search.
What guests that house contains, and bring them forth.
This Nobleman's misfortune stirs my quiet,
And fills my soul with fearful fantasies.
But I will unwind this Labyrinth of doubt,
Else industry shall lose part of itselfs labour.
Who have we there? Seigniors cannot you tell us
How our Princes kinsman came wounded to the death
Nigh to your houses.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Hey-day; cross-ruff at midnight. Is it Christmas?
You go a gaming to your neighbours house.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Dost make a Mummer of me Ox-head?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Make answer Gentlemen, it doth concern you.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Ox-head will bear an action; I will have the Law; I will not
be yoked. Bear witness Gentlemen, he calls me Ox-head,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Very well, very well, take Law and hang thyself, I
care not. Had she no other but that good face to dote upon?
I would rather she had dealt with a dangerous French-man, than
with such a Pagan.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Are you mad? answer my demand.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
I am as good a Christian as thyself,
Though my Wife have now new christened me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Are you deaf, you make no answer?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Would I had had the circumcising of thee Jew, I would have
Cut short your Cuckold-maker, I would i'faith, I would i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Away with them to prison; they will answer better there.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Not too fast Gentlemen: what is our crime?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Murther of the Dukes kinsman, Signior Mendosa.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Nothing else? we did it, we did it, we did it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Take heed Gentlemen what you confess.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
I will confess anything since I am made a fool by a knave.
I will be hanged like an innocent, that is flat.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
I will not see my shame. Hemp in stead of a Quack-salver,
you shall put out mine eyes, and my head shall be bought to make
Ink-horns of.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You do confess the murder?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Sir, it is true,
Done by a faithless Christian and a Jew.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
To prison with them, we will hear no further,
The tongue betrays the heart of guilty murder.

div2.stage: Enter Count Gvido, Isabella, Anna, and Seruants.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Welcome to Pauy sweet, and may this kiss
Chase Melancholy from thy company:
Speak my soul's joy, how fare you after travel.

sp.speaker: Isah.
sp.p:
Like one that scapeth dangers on the Seas,
Yet trembles with cold fears being safe on land,
With bare imagination of what is past.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Fear keep with cowards, air-stars cannot move.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Fear in this kind, my Lord, doth sweeten love.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: To think fear joy (dear) I cannot conjecture.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Fear is sire to fervency,
Which makes love's sweet prone Nectar:
Trembling desire, fear, hope, and doubtful leisure,
Distill from love the Quintessence of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Madam, I yield to you; Fear keeps with Love,
My Oratory is too weak against you:
You have the ground of knowledge, wise experience,
Which makes your argument invincible.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You are Time's Scholar, and can flatter weakness.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Custom allows it, and we plainly see
Princes and women maintain flattery.

div2.stage: Enter Gniaca Count of Gaza, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Anna, go see my Jewels and my Trunks
Be aptly placed in their several rooms.
My Lord, know you this Gallant? it is a complete Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: I do; it is Count Gniaca, my endeared friend.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
Isab.
sp.p: A rare shaped man: compare them both together,

sp.speaker: Guid.
Isab.
sp.p:
He is fairer than he was when first I saw him.
This little time makes him more excellent.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.p:
Relate some news. Hark you, what Lady is that.
Be open breasted, so will I to thee.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Error did blind him that paints Love blind;
For my Love plainly judges difference:
Love is clear sighted, and with Eagles eyes,
Undazzled, looks upon bright Sun-beamed beauty:
Nature did rob herself, when she made him,
Blushing to see her work excel herself,
It is shape makes mankind femelacy.
Forgive me Rogero, it is my Fate
To love thy friend, and quit thy love with hate.
I must enjoy him, let hope thy passions smother:
Faith cannot cool blood; I will clip him, were it my brother.
Such is the heat of my sincere affection,
Hell nor earth can keep love in subjection.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.p:
I crave your Honour's pardon my Ignorance
Of what you were, may gain a courteous pardon.

sp.speaker: Is.
Guid.
sp.p: What sport affords this Climate for delight?

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.p:
We will hawk and hunt today, as for tomorrow
Variety shall feed variety.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p:
Dissimulation women's armour is,
Aid love belief, and female constancy.
O, I am sick my Lord, kind Rogero help me.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p:
Forfend it heaven, Madam sit; how fare you?
My life's best comfort speak, O speak sweet Saint.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p:
Fetch Art to keep life, run my Love, I faint:
My vital breath runs coldly through my veins,
I see lean Death with eyes imaginary,
Stand fearfully before me: here my end
A wife unconstant, yet thy loving friend.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: As swift as thought, fly I to wish thee aid.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Thus innocence by craft is soon betrayed.
My Lord Gniaca, it is your Art must heal me,
I am love-sick for your love; love, love, for loving:
I blush for speaking truth; fair Sir believe me,
Beneath the Moon naught but your frown can grieve me.

sp.speaker: Gniaca.
sp.p: Lady, by heaven, methinks, this fit is strange.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Count not my love light for this sudden change:
By Cupids Bow I swear, and will avow,
I never knew true perfect love till now.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.p:
Wrong not yourself, me, and your dearest friend,
Your love is violent, and soon will end.
Love is not Love unless Love doth persevere,
That love is perfect love, that loves for ever.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Such love is mine, believe it well-shaped youth,
Though women use to lie, yet I speak truth.
Give sentence for my life or speedy death:
Can you affect me?

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.p:
I should belie my thoughts to give denial,
But then to friendship I must turn disloyal:
I will not wrong my friend, let that suffice.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I will be a miracle, for love a woman dies,

sp.speaker: Gn.
sp.p:
Hold madam, these are soul killing passions.
I would rather wrong my friend than you yourself.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Love me, or else by Jove death is but delayed:
My vow is fixed in heaven, fear shall not move me,
My life is death with tortures unless you love me.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.p: Give me some respite, and I will resolve you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
My heart denies it.
My blood is violent, now or else never,
Love me, and like love's Queen I will fall before thee,
Enticing dalliance from thee with my smiles,
And steal thy heart with my delicious kisses.
I will study Art in love, that in a rupture
Thy soul shall taste pleasures excelling nature.
Love me, both Art and nature in large recompense,
Shall be profuse in ravishing thy sense.

sp.speaker: Gni.
sp.p:
You have prevailed, I am yours from all the world,
Thy wit and beauty have entranced my soul:
I long for dalliance, my blood burns like fire,
Hell's pain on earth is to delay desire.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I kiss thee for that breath, this day you hunt;
In midst of all your sports leave you Rogero,
Return to me whose life rests in thy sight,
Where pleasure shall make Nectar our delight.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
Isab.
sp.p:
Women are witless that cannot dissemble:
Now I am sick again: where is my Lord Rogero?
His love and my health's vanished both together.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Wrong not thy friend, dear friend, in thy extremes,
Here is a profound Hipocrates, my dear,
To minister to thee the spirit of health.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Your sight to me, my Lord, excels all Physic;
I am better far (my Love) than when you left me:
Your friend was comfortable to me at the last.
It was but a fit, my Lord, and now it is past.
Are all things ready sir?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Yes Madam, the house is fit.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.p: Desire in women is the life of wit.

div2.stage: Enter Abigal and Thais at seuerall doores.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
O partner, I am with child of laughter, and none but
you can be my Mid-wife: was there ever such a game at Noddy?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Our Husbands think they are fore-men of the Jury,
they hold the Heretic point of Predestination, and sure they
are born to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
They are like to prove men of judgment, but not
for killing of him that is yet alive, and well recovered.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
As soon as my man saw the Watch come up,
All his spirit was down.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
But though they have made us good sport in speech,
They did hinder us of good sport in action.
O wench, imagination is strong in pleasure.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
That is true: for the opinion my Good-man had of
enjoying you, made him do wonders.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Why should weak man, that is so soon satisfied, desire variety?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Their answer is, to feed on Pheasants continually
would breed a loathing.

sp.speaker: Abigall.
sp.p:
Then if we seek for strange flesh that have stomachs
at will, it is pardonable.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: Aye, if men had any feeling of it, but they judge us by themselves.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Well, we will bring them to the Gallows, and then,
like kind virgins, beg their lives, and after live at our pleasures,
and this bridle shall still rein them.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Faith, if we were disposed, we might seem as safe,
As if we had the broad seal to warrant it:
But that nights work will stick by me this forty weeks.
Come, shall we go visit the discontented Lady Lentulus?
Whom the Lord Mendosa has confessed to his Surgeon,
He would have robbed? I thought great men would but
Have robbed the poor, yet he the rich.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
He thought that the richer purchase, though with the
worse conscience: but we will to comfort her, and then go hear
our Husbands lamentations. They say mine has compiled an
ungodly volume of Satyres against women, and calls his book
The Snarl.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: But he is in hope his book will save him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: God defend that it should, or any that snarl in that fashion.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p:
Well wench, if I could be metamorphosed into thy shape,
I should have my husband pliant to me in his life,
And soon rid of him: for being weary with his continual motion,
He would dye of a consumption.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Make much of him, for all our wanton prize,
Follow the Proverb, Merry be and wise.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Time that devourest all mortality,
Run swiftly these few hours,
And bring Gniaca on thy aged shoulders,
That I may clip the rarest model of creation.
Do this gentle Time
And I will curl thine aged silver lock,
And dally with thee in delicious pleasure.
Medea-like I will renew thy youth;
But if thy frozen steps delay my love,
I will poison thee with murder, curse thy paths,
And make thee know a time of infamy.
Anna, give watch, and bring me certain notice
When Count Gniaca doth approach my house.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Madam I go.
I am kept for pleasure, though I never taste it.
For it is the usher's office still to cover
His Lady's private meetings with her Lover.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Desire, thou quenchless flame that burnest our souls,
Cease to torment me;
The dew of pleasure shall put out thy fire,
And quite consume thee with satiety.
Lust shall be cooled with lust, wherein I will prove,
The life of love is only saved by love.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Madam, he is coming,

div2.stage: Enter Gniaca in his hunting weedes.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Thou blessed Mercurie,
Prepare a banquet fit to please the Gods;
Let Sphere-like Music breathe delicious tones
Into our mortal ears; perfume the house
With odoriferous scents, sweeter than Myrrh,
Or all the Spices in Panchaia:
His sight and touching we will recreate,
That his five Senses shall be five-fold happy.
His breath like Roses casts out sweet perfume;
Time now with pleasure shall itself consume.
How like Adonis in his hunting weeds,
Looks this same Goddess tempter?
And art thou come? this kiss entrance thy soul.
Gods I do not envy you; for know this
Way is here on earth complete, excels your bliss:
I will not change this nights pleasure with you all.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.p:
Thou creature made by Love, composed of pleasure,
That makest true use of thy creation,
In thee both wit and beauty's resident;
Delightful pleasure, unpeered excellence.
This is the fate fixed fast unto thy birth,
That thou alone shouldst be man's heaven on earth:
If I alone may but enjoy thy love,
I will not change earthly joy to be heaven's love:
For though that women haters now are common,
They all shall know earths joy consists in woman.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
My love was dotage till I loved thee;
For thy soul truly tastes our petulance,
Conditious Lover, Cupids Intelligencer,
That makes man understand what pleasure is:
These are fit attributes unto thy knowledge;
For women's beauty over men bear that rule.
Our power commands the rich, the wise, the fool.
Though scorn grows big in man in growth and stature,
Yet women are the rarest works in nature.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.p:
I do confess the truth, and must admire
That women can command rare man's desire.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Cease admiration, sit to Cupids feast,
The preparation to Papheon dalliance,
Harmonious Music breathe thy silver Airs,
To stir up appetite to Venus banquet,
That breath of pleasure that entrances souls,
Making that instant happiness a heaven,
In the true taste of love's deliciousness.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.p:
Thy words are able to stir cold desire,
Into his flesh that lies entombed in Ice,
Having lost the feeling use of warmth in blood,
Then how much more in me, whose youthful veins,
Like a proud River, over-flow their bounds?
Pleasures Ambrosia, or love's nourisher,
I long for privacy; come, let us in,
It is custom, and not reason makes love sin.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I will lead the way to Venus Paradise,
Where thou shalt taste that fruit that made man wise.

sp.speaker: Gnia.
sp.p:
Sing notes of pleasure to elate our blood:
Why should heaven frown on joys that do us good?
I come Isabella keeper of love's treasure,
To force thy blood to lust, and ravish pleasure.

div2.stage: After some short Song enter Isabella and Gniaca againe, she hanging about his necke laciuiously.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.p:
Still I am thy captive, yet thy thoughts are free:
To be Love's bond-man is true liberty.
I have swum in seas of pleasure without ground,
Venturous desire past depth itself hath drowned.
Such skill has beauties Art in a true lover,
That dead desire to life it can recover.
Thus beauty our desire can soon advance,
Then straight again kill it with dalliance.
Divinest women, your enchanting breaths
Give Lovers many lives and many deaths.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
May thy desire to me forever last,
Not dye by surfeit on my delicates:
And as I tie this Jewel about thy neck,
So may I tie thy constant love to mine,
Never to seek weaking variety,
That greedy curse of man's and woman's hell,
Where naught but shame and loathed diseases dwell.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.p:
You counsel well, dear, learn it then;
For change is given more to you than men.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
My faith to thee, like rocks, shall never move,
The Sun shall change his course ere I my love.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Madam, the Count Rogero knocks.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Dear Love into my chamber, till I send
My hate from sight.

sp.speaker: Gniac.
sp.p: Lust makes me wrong my friend.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Anna, stand here, and entertaine Lord Rogero.
I from my window straight will give him answer.
The Serpent's wit to woman rest in me,
By that man fell, then why not he by me?
Feigned sighs and tears dropped from a woman's eye,
Blinds man of reason, strikes his knowledge dumb:
Wit arms a woman, Count Rogero come.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p:
My office still is under: yet in time
Ushers prove Masters, degrees makes us climb.
Who knocks? is it you my noble Lord?

div2.stage: Enter Gvido in his hunting weedes.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Came my friend hither, Count Gniaca?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: No, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Where is my Isabella?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: In her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Good: I will visit her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The chamber is locked my Lord: she will be private.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Locked against me, my saucy malapert?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Be patient good my Lord: she will give you answer.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Isabella life of love, speak, it is I that calls.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I must desire your Lordship pardon me.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Lordship? what is this? Isabella, art thou blind?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
My Lord, my lust was blind, but now my soul is clear sighted,
And sees the spots that did corrupt my flesh:
Those tokens sent from hell, brought by desire,
The messenger of everlasting death.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: My Lady is in her Pulpit, now she will preach.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Is not thy Lady mad? in verity I always
Took her for a Puritan, and now she shows it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Mock not Repentance. Profanation
Brings mortals laughing to damnation.
Believe it Lord, Isabella's ill past life,
Like gold refined, shall make a perfect Wife.
I stand on firm ground now, before on Ice;
We know not vertue till we taste of vice.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Do you hear dissimulation, woman sinner?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Leave my house good my Lord, and for my part,
I look for a most wished reconciliation
Betwixt myself and my most wronged Husband.
Tempt not contrition then religious Lord.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Indeed I was one of your family once:
But do not I know these are but brain-tricks:
And where the Devil has the Fee-simple, he will keep possession.
And will you halt before me that yourself has made a cripple?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Nay, then you wrong me: and disdained Lord,
I paid thee for thy pleasures vendible,
Whose mercenary flesh I bought with coin,
I will divulge thy baseness, unless with speed
Thou leave my house and my society.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Already turned apostate, but now all pure,
Now damned your faith is, and loves endure
Like dew upon the grass, when pleasures Sun
Shines on your virtues, all your virtue is done.
I will leave thy house and thee, go get thee in,
Thou gaudy child of pride, and nurse of sin.

sp.speaker: Isab.
Anna.
sp.p: Your Lordship will command me no further service?

sp.speaker: Guid.
Anna.
sp.p: I hope I did discharge my place with care.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Ushers should have much wit, but little hair;
Thou hast of both sufficient: prithee leave me,
If thou hast an honest Lady, commend me to her,
But she is none.
Farewell thou private strumpet worse than common.
Man were on earth an Angel but for woman,
That seven-fold branch of hell from them doth grow,
Pride, Lust, and Murder, they raise from below,
With all their fellow sins. Women were made
Of blood, without souls: when their beauties fade,
And their lust is past, avarice or bawdry
Makes them still loved: then they buy venery,
Bribing damnation, and hire brothel slaves.
Shame is their executors, Infamy their graves.
Your painting will wipe off, which Art did hide,
And show your ugly shape in spite of pride.
Farewell Isabella poor in soul and fame,
I leave thee rich in nothing but in shame.
Then soulless women know, whose faiths are hollow,
Your lust being quenched, a bloody act must follow.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke of Amago, the Captaine, and the rest of the Watch, with the Senators.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Justice that makes Princes like the Gods, draws us unto the Senate,
That with unpartial balance we may poise
The crimes and innocence of all offenders,
Our presence can chase bribery from Laws:
He best can judge, that hears himself the cause.

sp.speaker: 1 Senat.
sp.p:
True mighty Duke, it best becomes our places,
To have our light from you the son of Vertue,
Subject Authority, for gain, love or fear
Oft quits the guilty, and condemns the clear.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
The Land and people is mine, the crimes being known,
I must redress my subiects' wrongs, mine own.
Call for the two suspected for the murder
Of Mendosa, our endeared kinsman. These voluntary murderers
That confess the Murder of him that is yet alive.
We will sport with serious Justice for a while,
In show we will frown on them that make us smile.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: Bring forth the Prisoners we may hear their answers.

div2.stage: Enter (brought in with Officers) Claridiana, andMizaldvs .

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Stand forth you Vipers, that have sucked blood,
And lopped a branch sprung from a royal tree:
