What can you answer to escape tortures?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
We have confessed the fact my Lord, to God and man,
Our ghostly father, and that worthy Captain:
We beg not life but favourable death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: On what ground sprung your hate to him we loved?

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Upon that curse laid on Venecians jealousy.
We thought he being a Courtier, would have made us Magnificoes
of the right stamp, and have played at Primero in the
presence, with gold of the City brought from our Indies.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Nay more, my Lord, we feared that your kinsman for
a mess of Sonnets, would have given the plot of us and our
wives, to some needy Poet, and for sport and profit brought us
in some Venician Comedy upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Our Justice dwells with mercy; be not desperate.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p:
His Highness fain would save your lives if you would
see it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
All the Law in Venice shall not save me, I will not be
saved.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Fear not, I have a trick to bring us to hanging in spite of the Law.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Why now I see thou lovest me; thou hast confirmed
Thy friendship for ever to me by these words.
Why, I should never hear Lantern and candle called for,
But I should think it was for me and my Wife.
I will hang for that, forget not thy trick.
Upon them with thy trick, I long for sentence.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: Will you appeal for mercy to the Duke?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Kill not thy Justice Duke, to save our lives:
We have deserved death.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Make not us presidents for after wrongs,
I will receive punishment for my sins,
It shall be a means to lift me towards heaven.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Let us have our desert; we crave no favour.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Take them asunder, grave Justice makes us mirth,
That man is soulless that never sins on earth.
Signior Mizaldus, relate the weapon you killed him with, and
the manner.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
My Lord, your lustful kinsman, I can title him no better,
came sneaking to my house like a Promoter to spy flesh in
the Lent: now I having a Venecian spirit, watched my time, and
with my Rapier run him through, knowing all pains are but
trifles to the horn of a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Take him aside. Signior Claridiana, what weapon had
you for this bloody act? what dart used Death?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
My Lord, I brained him with a lever my neighbour
lent me, and he stood by and cried strike home old boy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
With several Instruments. Bring them face to face.
With what killed you our Nephew?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: With a Rapier Liege.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
It is a lie,
I killed him with a lever, and thou stoodest by.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Dost think to save me and hang thyself? no I scorn it; is this
the trick thou saidst thou hadst: I killed him Duke.
He only gave consent: it was I that did it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Thou hast always been cross to me and wilt be to my
death. Have I taken all this pains to bring thee to hanging, and
dost thou slip now?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
We shall never agree in a tale till we come to the gallows,
then we shall jump.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
I will show you a cross point, if you cross me thus,
When thou shalt not see it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
I will make a wry mouth at that, or it shall cost me a fall:
It is thy pride to be hanged alone, because thou scornest my company:
but it shall be known I am as good a man as thyself, and
in these actions will keep company with thy betters Jew.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Monster.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Dog-killer.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Fencer.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Part them, part them.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Hang us, and quarter us, we shall never be parted till then,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You do confess the murther done by both.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
But that I would not have the slave laugh at me,
And count me a coward, I have a very good mind to live,
But I am resolute: it is but a turn. I do confess.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
So do I,
Pronounce our doom, we are prepared to dye.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.p:
We sentence you to hang till you be dead:
Since you were men eminent in place and worth,
We give a Christian burial to you both,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Not in one grave together we beseech you, we shall never agree.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
He scorns my company, till the day of Judgment,
I will not hang with him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
You hang together, that shall make you friends,
An everlasting hatred death soon ends:
To prison with them till the day of death;
Kings words like Fate, must never change their breath.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
You malice-monger, I will be hanged afore thee,
If it be but to vex thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I will do you as good a turn or the hangman, and shall fall out.

div2.stage: Enter Mendosa in his night gowne and cap guarded, with the Captaine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Now to our kinsman, shame to royal blood,
Bring him before us.
Theft in a Prince is sacrilege to honour
It is virtue's scandal, death of Royalty,
I blush to see my shame; Nephew sit down
Justice that smiles on those on him must frown,
Speak freely Captain, where found you him wounded?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Between the widow's house and these cross neighbours,
Besides an Artificial ladder made of ropes
Was fastened to her window which he confessed
He brought to rob her of Jewels and coin.
My knowledge yields no further circumstance.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Thou knowest too much, would I were past all knowledge,
I might forget my grief springs from my shame,
Thou monster of my blood, answer in brief
To these Assertions made against thy life.
Is thy soul guilty of so base a fact?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
I do confess I did intend to rob her.
In the attempt I fell and hurt myself
Laws thunder is but death, I dread it not,
So my Lentulus honour be preserved
From black suspicion of a lustful night.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Thy head is thy forfeit for thy heart's offence,
Thy bloods prerogative may claim that favour,
Thy person then to death doomed by just laws,
Thy death is infamous, but worse the cause.

div2.stage: Enter Isabella alone Gviaca following her.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
O heavens that I was born to be hates slave,
The food of Rumour, that devours my fame;
I am called Insatiate Countess lusts paramour
A glorious Devil, and the noble whore,
I am sick, vexed, and tormented, O revenge.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p: On whom would my Isabella be revenged?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Upon a Viper, that does get mine honour,
I will not name him till I be revenged,
See, here is the Libels are divulged against me,
An everlasting scandal to my name.
And thus the villain writes in my disgrace.

Who loves Isabella the insatiate,
Needs Atlas back for to content her lust,
That wandering Strumpet, and chaste wedlock's hate,
That renders truth: deceit for loyal trust,
That sacrilegious thief to Hymen's rights,
Making her lust her God, heaven her delights.
Swell not proud heart, I will quench thy grief in blood,
Desire in woman cannot be withstood.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p:
I will be thy champion sweet gainst all the world,
Name but the villain that defames thee thus.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Dare thy hand execute, whom my tongue condemns,
Then art thou truly valiant, mine for ever,
But if thou fainest, hate must our true love sever.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p:
By my dead father's soul, my mothers virtues,
And by my knight hood and gentility; I will be revenged
On all the Authors of your Obloquy: Name him.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
What does his name affright thee coward Lord?
Be mad Isabella, curse on thy revenge,
This Lord was knighted for his father's worth,
Not for his own.
Farewell thou perjured man, I will leave you all,
You all conspire to work mine honour's fall.

sp.speaker: Guia.
sp.p:
Stay my Isabella, were he my father's son,
Composed of me, he dies,
Delight still keep with thee: go in.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
Thou art just:
Revenge to me is sweeter now than lust.

div2.stage: Enter Gvido: they see one another and draw and make a passe, then enter Anna.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: What mean you Nobles, will you kill each other?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p: Thou shame to friendship, what intends thy hate?

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p:
Love Arms my hand, makes my soul valiant,
Isabellas wrongs now sits upon my sword,
To fall more heavy to thy cowards head,
Than thunderbolts upon Jove's rifted Oaks:
Deny thy scandal, or defend thy life.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p:
What? hath thy faith and and reason left thee both?
That thou art only flesh without a soul:
Hast thou no feeling of thyself and me?
Blind rage that will not let thee see thyself.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p:
I come not to dispute but execute:
And thus comes death.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p: And thus I break thy dart, here is at thy whores face.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p: It is missed: here is at thy heart, stay, let us breath.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p:
Let reason govern rage, yet let us leave,
Although most wrong be mine, I can forgive:
In this attempt, thy shame will ever live.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p:
Thou hast wronged the Phenix of all women rarest,
She that is most wise, most loving, chaste and fairest.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Thou dotest upon a devil, not a woman,
That has bewitched thee with her Sorcery,
And drowned thy soul in lethy faculties,
Her useless lust has benumbed thy knowledge,
Thy intellectual powers, oblivion smothers,
That thou art nothing but forgetfulness.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p:
What is this to my Isabella, my sins mine own,
Her faults were none, until thou madest them known.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p:
Leave her, and leave thy shame where first thou
foundest it;
Else live a bond slave to diseased lust,
Devoured in her gulf-like appetite
And infamy shall write thy Epitaph,
Thy memory leaves nothing but thy crimes,
A scandal to thy name in future times.

sp.speaker: Guia.
sp.p:
Put up your weapon, I dare here you further,
Insatiate lust is Sire still to murther.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p:
Believe it friend, if her heart blood were vexed,
Though you kill me, new pleasure makes you next:
She loved me dearer, than she loves you now,
She will never be faithful, has twice broke her vow.
This curse pursues female Adultery,
They will swim through blood for sin's variety:
Their pleasure like a sea groundless and wide,
A woman's lust was never satisfied.

sp.speaker: Guia.
sp.p:
Fear whispers in my breast, I have a soul
That blushes red, for tending bloody facts,
Forgive me friend, if I can be forgiven,
Thy counsel is the path leads me to heaven.

sp.speaker: Guia.
sp.p: I do embrace thy reconciled love.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p:
That death or danger, now shall never remove,
Go tell thy Insatiate Countess Anna,
We have escaped the snares of her false Love,
Vowing for ever to abandon her.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: You have heard our Resolution, pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p:
My office ever rested at your pleasure,
I was the Indian, yet you had the treasure.
My faction often sweats, and oft takes cold,
Then gild true diligence over with gold.

sp.speaker: Guia.
sp.p:
Thy speech deserves it there is gold,
Be honest now, and not loves Noddy,
Turned up and played on whilst thou keepest the stock,
Prithee formally let us have thy absence.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Lords farewell.

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p: It is Whores and Panders, that makes earth like hell.

sp.speaker: Guiaca.
sp.p:
Now I am got out of lusts Labyrinth,
I will to Venice, for a certain time,
To recreate my much abused spirits,
And then revisit Pani and my friend,

sp.speaker: Guido.
sp.p:
I will bring you on your way but must return,
Lust is like Aetna, and will ever burn.
Yet now desire is quenched flamed once in height:
Till man knows hell, he never has firm faith.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
Our screech-owl messenger of my revenge's death
Thou dost belie Guiaca it is not so.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Upon mine honesty they are united.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
Thy honesty? thou vassal to my pleasure take
that,
Darest thou control me, when I say no?
Art not my footstool, did not I create thee?
And made thee gentle, being born a beggar:
Thou hast been my woman's Pander for a crown,
And dost thou stand upon thy honesty?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: I am, what you please Madam. Yet it is so.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Slave, I will slit thy tongue, less thou say no.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: No, no, no Madam.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
I have my humour, though they now be false,
Faint-hearted coward get thee from my sight,
When villain? haste, and come not near me.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Madam: I run, her sight like death doth fear me.

div2.stage: Enter Don Sago a Coronell, with a band of Souldiers and a Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
Perfidious cowards, stain of Nobility,
Venecians, and be reconciled with words:
O that I had Guiaca once more here,
Within this prison, made of flesh and bone,
I would not trust Thunder with my fell revenge,
But mine own hands, should do the dire exploit,
And fame should Chronicle a woman's acts:
My rage respects the persons not the facts.
There place and worths hath power to defame me,
Mean hate is stingless, and does only name me:
I not regard it, it is high blood that swells,
Give me revenge, and damn me into hells,
A gallant Spaniard, I will hear him speak,
Grief must be speechless, ere the heart can break.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Lieutenant let good Discipline be used
In quartering of our Troops within the City,
Not separated into many streets,
That shows weak love, but not sound policy.
Division in small numbers makes all weak,
Forces united are the nerves of war,
Mother and nurse of observation.
Whose rare ingenious sprite, fills all the world
By looking on itself with piercing eyes,
Will look through strangers imbecilities:
Therefore be careful.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p:
All shall be ordered fitting your command,
For these three gifts which makes a Soldier rare,
Is love and duty with a valiant care.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
What rarety of women feeds my sight,
And leads my senses in a maze of wonder?
Bellona, thou wert my mistress till I saw that shape
But now my sword, I will consecrate to her,
Leave Mars and become Cupids Martialist,
Beauty can turn the rugged face of war,
And make him smile upon delightful peace,
Courting her smoothly like a femalist,
I grow a slave unto my potent love,
Whose power change hearts, make our fate remove.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
Revenge not, Pleasure now ore-rules my blood,
Rage shall drown faint love in a crimson flood,
And were he caught, I would make him murders hand.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Methinks it were joy to die at her command,
I will speak to hear her speech, whose powerful breath,
Is able to infuse life into death.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: He comes to speak: he is mine, by love he is mine.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Lady, think bold intrusion courtesy,
It is but imagination alters them,
Then it is your thoughts, not I, that do offend.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
Sir, your intrusion yet is but courtesy,
Unless your future humour alter it.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Why then Divinest woman, know my soul
Is dedicated to thy shrine of beauty,
To pray for mercy, and repent the wrongs
Done against love, and female purity.
Thou abstract drawn from natures empty store-house,
I am thy slave, command my sword, my heart
The soul is tried best by the bodies smart.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
You are a stranger to this land and me,
What madness is it for me to trust you then?
To cozen women is a trade amongst men,
Smooth promises, faint passions with a lie,
Deceives our sex of fame and chastity:
What danger durst you hazard for my love?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Perils "that never mortal durst approve.
I will double all the works of Hercules,
Expose myself in combat againstagainst an Host,
Meet danger in a place of certain death,
Yet never shrink, or give way to my Fate;
Bare-breasted meet the murderous Tartars dart,
Or any fatal Engine made for death:
Such power has love and beauty from your eyes,
He that dies resolute, does never die:
It is fear gives death his strength, which I resisted,
Death is but empty Air, the Fates have twisted.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Dare you revenge my quarrel, against a foe?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Then ask me if I dare embrace you thus,
Or kiss your hand, or gaze on your bright eye,
Where Cupid dances, on those globes of love,
Fear is my vassal, when I frown he flies,
A hundred times in life, a coward dies.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: I not suspect your valour, but your will.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: To gain your love, my father's blood I will spill.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Many have sworn the like, yet broke their vow.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
My whole endeavour to your wish shall bow.
I am your plague to scourge your enemies.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
Perform your promise, and enjoy your pleasure,
Spend my love's Dowry, that is women's treasure:
But if thy resolution dread the trial,
I will tell the world, a Spaniard was disloyal.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Relate your grief, I long to hear their names,
Whose bastard spirits, thy true worth defames:
I will wash thy scandal off, when their hearts bleeds,
Valour makes difference betwixt words and deeds.
Tell thy fames poison, blood shall wash thee white,

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
My spotless honour, is a slave to spite:
These are the monsters Venice doth bring forth,
Whose empty souls are bankrupt of true worth.
False Count Guido, treacherous Guiaca,
Countess of Gazia, and of rich Massino.
Then if thou beest a Knight, help the oppressed,
Through danger safety comes, through trouble rest.
And so my love.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Ignoble villains, their best blood shall prove,
Revenge falls heavy, that is raised by love.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Think what reproach is to a woman's name,
Honoured by birth, by marriage, and by beauty:
Be God on earth, and revenge innocence,
O worthy Spaniard, on my knees I beg,
Forget the persons, think on their offence.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
By the white soul of honour, by heaven's Jove:
They die if their death can attain your love.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Thus will I clip thy waste, embrace thee thus:
Thus dally with thy hair, and kiss thee thus:
Our Pleasures Protean-like in sundry shapes,
Shall with variety stir dalliance.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
I am immortal, O divinest creature:
Thou dost excel the Gods, in wit and feature.
False Counts you die, revenge now shakes his rods:
Beauty condemns you, stronger than the Gods.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Come Mars of lovers, Vulcan is not here,
Make vengeance like my bed, quite void of fear.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
My senses are entranced, and in this slumber,
I taste heaven's joys, but cannot count the number.

div2.stage: Enter Lady Lentvlvs, Abigall and Thais.

sp.speaker: Abigal.
sp.p:
Well Madam: you see the destiny that follows
marriage,
Our husbands are quiet now, and must suffer the law.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
If my husband had been worth the begging some
Courtier would have had him: he might be begged well enough,
for he knows not his own wife from another.

sp.speaker: Lady Lent.
sp.p:
O you are a couple of trusty wenches, to deceive
your husbands thus.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
If we had not deceived them thus, we had been Trust
wenches.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Our husbands will be hanged, because they think
themselves Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
If all true Cuckolds were of that mind, the hangman
would be the richest occupation, and more wealthy widows,
than there be younger brothers to marry them.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: The Merchant venturers would be a very small company.

sp.speaker: Abag.
sp.p:
It is twelve to one of that, how ever the rest scape,
I shall fear a massacre.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
If my husband hereafter for his wealth chance to
be dubbed:
I will have him called the Knight of the supposed horn.

sp.speaker: Abag.
sp.p: Faith, and it sounds well.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Come madcaps leave jesting, and let us deliver them
out of their earthly purgation; you are the spirits that torment
them: but my love and Lord, kind Mendosa, will lose his
life, to preserve mine honour, not for hate to others.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
By my troth, if I had been his judge, I should have
hanged him for having no more wit, I speak as I think, for I
would not be hanged for never a man under the heavens.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Faith, I think I should for my Husband. I do not
hold the opinion of the Philosopher, that writes we love them
best, that we enjoy first: for I protest I love my husband better
than any that did know me before.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
So do I, yet life and pleasure are two sweet things to
a woman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He that is willing to die to save mine honour, I will die to save his.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Tut: believe it who that list, we love a lively man I
grant you:
But to maintain that life, I will never consent to die.
This is a rule I still will keep in breast,
Love well thy husband wench, but thyself best.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
I have followed your counsel hitherto, and mean
to do still.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Come: we neglect our business, it is no jesting,
Tomorrow they are executed unless we reprieve them,
We be their destinies to cast their fate.
Let us all go.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: I fear not to come late.

div2.stage: Enter Don Sago Solvs with a case of Pistols.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Day was my night, and night must be my day:
The sun shined on my pleasure, with my lone,
And darkness must lend aid to my revenge,
The stage of heaven, is hung with solemn black,
A time best fitting, to Act Tragedies,
The nights great Queen, that maiden governess
Musters black clouds, to hide her from the world,
Afraid to look on my bold enterprise.
Cursed creatures messengers of death, possess the world,
night-ravens, screech-owls, and vote-killing Mandrakes,
The ghosts of misers, that imprisoned gold,
Within the harmless bowels of the earth,
Are nights companions: bawds to lust and murder,
Be all propitious to my Act of justice:
Upon the scandalizers of her fame,
That is the life-blood of deliciousness,
Deemed Isabella, Cupids Treasurer.
Whose soul contains the richest gifts of love:
Her beauty from my heart, fear doth expel;
They relish pleasure best, that dread not hell.
Who is there?

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: A friend to thee, if thy intents be just and honourable.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Count Rogero, speak, I am the watch.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: My name is Rogero: dost thou know me?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Yes slanderous villain, nurse of Obloquy,
Whose poisoned breath, has speckled clear faced vertue,
And made a Leper of Isabella's fame,
That is as spotless, as the eye of heaven.
Thy vital threads a cutting, start not slave,
He is sure of sudden death, heaven cannot save.

sp.speaker: Count Rog.
sp.p:
Art not Guiaca turned Apostata, has pleasure once again
Turned thee again a devil, art not Guiaca? ha!

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
O that I were, then would I stab myself,
For he is marked for death, as well as thee:
I am Don Sago thy mortal enemy,
Whose hand love makes thy executioner.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
I know thee valiant Spaniard, and to thee
Murders more hateful, than is sacrilege
Thy actions ever have been honourable.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
And this the crown of all my Actions,
To purge the earth, of such a man turned monster.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
I never wronged thee Spaniard, did I? speak
I will make thee satisfaction like a soldier,
A true Italian, and a Gentleman:
Thy rage is treachery without a cause.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
My rage is just, and thy heart blood shall know,
He that wrongs beauty, must be honour's foe:
Isabels quarrel, arms the Spaniards spirit.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
Murder should keep with baseness, not with merit:
I will answer thee tomorrow by my soul,
And clear thy doubts, or satisfy thy will.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
He is war's best scholar, can with safety kill.
Take this tonight, now meet with me tomorrow,
I come Isabella, half thy hate is dead,
Valour makes murder light, which fear makes dead.

div2.stage: Enter Capt. with a band of Soldiors.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
The pistol was shot here seize him,
Bring lights, what Don Sago Colonel of the horse?
Ring the Alarum bell, raise the whole City,
His Troops are in the town, I fear treachery:
Who is this lies murdered, speak bloodthirsty Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: I have not spoiled his face, you may know his physiognomy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
It is Count Rogero, go convey him hence.
Thy life proud Spaniard, answers this offence,
A strong guard for the prisoner, less the cities powers
Rise to rescue him.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
What needs this strife?
Know slaves, I prize revenge above my life.
Fames register to future times shall tell
That by Don Sago, Count Rogero fell.

div2.stage: Enter Medina, the dead body of Gvido Alias Count Arsena, and Souldiours, Don Sago guarded, Executioner, Scaffold.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p:
DonSago quakest thou not to behold this spectacle,
This innocent sacrifice murdered nobleness,
When blood the maker ever promiseth,
Shall though with slow yet with sure vengeance rest.
It is a guerdon earned, and must be paid,
As sure revenge, as it is sure a deed:
I never knew murder yet, bury did bleed.
Canst thou after so many fearful conflicts,
Between this object, and thy guilty conscience,
Now thou art freed from out the serpent's Jaws,
That vile Adulteress, whose sorceries
Doth draw chaste men into incontinence:
Whose tongue flows over with harmful eloquence.
Canst thou I say repent this heinous Act,
And learn to loath, that killing Cockatrice?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
By this fresh blood, that from thy manly breast,
I cowardly sluiced out, I would in hell,
From this sad minute, still the day of doom:
To re-inspire vain AEsculapius.
And fill these crimson conduits, feel the fire
Due to the damned, and this horrid fact

sp.speaker: Medina
sp.p: Upon my soul, brave Spaniard, I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
O cease to weep in blood, or teach me too,
The bubbling wounds, do murmur for revenge:
This is the end of lust, where men may see,
Murders the shadow of Adultery:
And follows it to death.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p:
But hopeful Lord, we do commiserate,
Thy bewitched fortunes, a free pardon give:
On this thy true and noble penitence.
With all we make thee Colonel of our horse;
Levied against the proud Venecian state.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p:
Medina, I thank thee not, give life to him,
That sits with Risus, and the full cheeked Bacchus,
The rich and mighty Monarchs of the earth,
To me life is ten times more terrible,
Than death can be to me, O break my breast:
Divines and dying men may talk of hell,
But in my heart the several torments dwell.
What Tanais, Nilus? or what Tioris swift?
What Rhenus furrier then the Cataract?
Although Neptolis cold, the waves of all the northern sea,
Should flow for ever, through these guilty hands,
Yet the sanguinolent stain would extant be.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p: God pardon thee, we do.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p:
The Countess comes my Lord, unto the death:
But so unwillingly, and unprepared,
That she is rather forced, thinking the sum
She sent to you of twenty thousand pound,
Would have assured her of life.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p:
O Heavens!
Is she not weary yet of lust and life?
Had it been Cressus wealth, she should have died;
Her goods by law, are all confiscate to us,
And die she shall: her lust
Would make a slaughter house of Italy,
Ere she attained to four and twenty years,
Three Earls, one Viscount, and this valiant Spaniard,
Are known to have been the fuel to her lust:
Besides her secret lovers, which charitably
I judge to have been but few, but some they were,
Here is a glass, wherein to view her soul,
A Noble, but unfortunate Gentleman,
Cropped by her hand, as some rude passenger
Doth pluck the tender Roses in the bud,
Murder and lust, the least of which is death,
And hath she yet any false hope of breath?

div2.stage: Enter Isabella, with her haire hanging downe, a chaplet of flower on her head, a nosegay in her hand, Executioner before her, and with her a Cardinall

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: What place is this?

sp.speaker: Cardin.
sp.p: Madam, the Castle green.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: There should be dancing on a green I think.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Madam: to you none other than your dance of death.

sp.speaker: Isabell.
sp.p:
Good my Lord Cardinal do not thunder thus,
I sent today to my Physician,
And as he says he finds no sign of death.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Good Madam, do not jest away your soul.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
O servant, how hast thou betrayed my life?
Thou art my dearest lover now I see.
Thou wilt not leave me, till my very death.
Blessed be thy hand, I sacrifice a kiss
To it and vengeance: worthily thou didst,
He died deservedly, not content to enjoy
My youth and beauty, riches and my fortune:
But like a Chronicler of his own vice,
In Epigrams and songs, he tuned my name,
Renowned me for a Strumpet in the Courts,
Of the French King, and the great Emperor.
Didst thou not kill him drunk.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p: O shameless woman!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Thou shouldst, or in the embraces of his lust,
It might have been a woman's vengeance.
Yet I thank thee Sago, and would not wish him living
Were my life instant ransom.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: O Madam: in your soul have charity.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: There is money for the poor.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p:
O Lady this is but a branch of charity,
An ostentation, or a liberal pride:
Let me instruct your soul, for that, I fear,
Within the painted sepulchre of flesh,
Lies in a dead consumption: good Madam, read,

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
You put me to my book my Lord, will
not that save me.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Yes Madam, in the everlasting world.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
While thou wert my servant, thou hast ever said,
Amen to all my wishes, witness this spectacle:
Where my Lord Medina?

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p: Here Isabella. What would you?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: May we not be reprieved?

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p: Mine honour is past, you may not.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: No, it is my honour past,

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p: Thine honour is past indeed.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Then there is no hope of absolute remission.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p:
For that your holy Confessor will tell you,
Be dead to this world, for I swear you dye,
Were you my father's daughter.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Can you do nothing my Lord Cardinal?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p:
More than the world sweet Lady, help to save
What hand of man, wants power to destroy.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
You are all for this world, then why not I?
Were you in health and youth, like me my Lord,
Although you merited the crown of life,
And stood in state of grace, assured of it:
Yet in this fearful separation,
Old as you are, even till your latest gasp,
You would crave the help of the Physician:
And wish your days lengthened one summer longer,
Though all be grief, labour and misery,
Yet none will part with it, that I can see.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p: Up to the scaffold with her, it is late.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Better late than never my good Lord you think:
You use square dealing, Medina's mighty Duke:
Tyrant of France, sent hither by the devil.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p: The fitter to meet you.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Peace: Good my Lord in death do not provoke her.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Servant low as my destiny I kneel to thee,
Honouring in death, thy manly loyalty:
And whatsoever become of my poor soul,
The joys of both worlds evermore be thine.
Commend me to the Noble Count Guiaca,
That should have shared thy valour, and my hatred:
Tell him I pray his pardon, and
Medina, art yet inspired from heaven,
Show thy Creators Image: be like him,
Father of mercy.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p: Head's man, do thine office.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Now God lay all thy sins upon thy head,
And sink thee with them, to infernal darkness,
Thou teacher of the furies cruelty.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p:
O Madam: teach yourself a better prayer,
This is your latest hour.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
He is mine enemy, his sight torments me,
I shall not die in quiet.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I will be gone: off with her head there.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Takest thou delight, to torture misery?
Such mercy find thou in the day of doom.

div2.stage: Enter Roberto Count of Cipres in Friers weeds.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.p:
My Lord: here is a holy Friar desires,
To have some conference with the prisoners.

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.p:
It is in private, what I have to say,
With favour of your father-hood.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Friar: in Gods name welcome.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Lady: it seems your eye is still the same,
Forgetful of what most it should behold,
Do not you know me then?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Holy Sir: so far you are gone from my memory,
I must take truce with time, ere I can know you.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p:
Bear record all, you blessed Saints in heaven,
I come not to torment thee in thy death:
For of himself he is terrible enough,
But call to mind a Lady like yourself.
And think how ill in such a beauteous soul,
Upon the instant morrow of her nuptials,
Apostasy and vile revolt would show:
With all imagine that she had a Lord,
Jealous, the Air should ravish her chaste looks:
Doting like the creator in his models,
Who views them every minute, and with care,
Mixed in his fear of their obedience to him.
Suppose he sung through famous Italy,
More common than the looser songs of Petrarch:
To every several Zanies instrument,
And he poor wretch, hoping some better sate,
Might call her back from her Adulterate purpose:
Lives in obscure, and almost unknown life,
Till hearing, that she is condemned to die:
For he once loved her, lends his pined corps,
Motion to bring him to her stage of honour
Where drowned in woe: at her so dismal chance,
He clasps her: thus he falls into a trance.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
O my offended Lord lift up your eyes:
But yet avert them from my loathed sight.
Had I with you enjoyed the lawful pleasure,
To which belongs, nor fear, nor public shame:
I might have lived in honour, died in fame.
Your pardon on my faltering knees I beg:
Which shall confirm more peace unto my death,
Then all the grave instructions of the Church.

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.p:
Pardon belongs unto my holy weeds,
Freely thou hast it, farewell my Isabella.
Let thy death ransom thy soul, O die a rare example,
The kiss thou gavest me in the church, here take,
As I leave thee, so thou the world forsake.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Rare accident, ill welcome noble Lord:
Madam: your executioner desires you to forgive him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yes and give him too, what must I do my friend?

sp.speaker: Executioner.
sp.p: Madam: only tie up your hair.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
O these golden nets,
That have ensnared so many wanton youths,
Not one but has been held a thread of life,
And superstitiously depended on,
Now to the block, we must veil: what else?

sp.speaker: Executioner.
sp.p: Madam: I must entreat you blind your eyes.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
I have lived too long in darkness my friend:
And yet mine eyes with their majestic light,
Have got new Muses, in a Poets sprite.
They have been more gazed at than the God of Day:
Their brightness never could be flattered,
Yet thou commandest a fixed cloud of Lawn,
To Eclipse eternally these minutes of light.
What else?

sp.speaker: Executioner.
sp.p:
Now Madam: all is done,
And when you please, I will execute my office.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
We will be for thee straight.
Give me your blessing my Lord Cardinal:
Lord, I am well prepared:
Murder and lust, down with my ashes sink.
But like ingrateful seed perish in earth,
That you may never spring against my soul,
Like weeds to choke it in the heavenly harvest,
I fall to rise, mount to thy maker, spirit,
Leave here thy body, death has her demerit.

sp.speaker: Cardin.
sp.p: An host of Angels be thy convey hence.

sp.speaker: Medina.
sp.p:
To funeral with her body, and this Lords:
None here I hope can tax us of injustice:
She died deservedly, and may like fate,
Attend all women so insatiate.

div2.stage: Enter Amago the Duke, the Watch and Senators.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I am amazed at this maze of wonder,
Wherein no thread or clue presents itself,
To wind us from the obscure passages,
What says my Nephew?

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: Still resolute my Lord, and doth confess the theft.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
We will use him like a felon, cut him off:
For fear he do pollute our sounder parts.
Yet why should he steal,
That is a laden Vine? riches to him,
Were adding sands into the Libian shore,
Or far less charity: what say the other prisoners?

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p:
Like men my Lord, fit for the other world,
They take it upon their death, they slew your Nephew.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
And he is yet alive, keep them asunder
We may sent out the wile.

div2.stage: Enter Claridiana and Rogero bound: with a Frier and Officers.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
My friend; is it the rigour of the law
I should be tied thus hard, I will undergo it:
If not, prithee then slacken; yet I have deserved it,
This murder lies heavy on my conscience.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Wedlock, Aye here is my wedlock; O whore, whore,
whore.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.p: O Sir be qualified.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Sir: I am to die a dog's death, and will snarl a
little
At the old Seignior, you are only a Parenthesis,
Which I will leave out of my execrations: but first
To our quondam wives, that makes us cry our Vowels
In red Capital letters, Iov are cuckolds, O may
Bastard bearing with the pangs of childbirth, be
Doubled to him: may they have ever twins
And be three weeks in travel between, may they be,
So Rivelled with painting by that time they are thirty, that it
May be held a work of condign merit
But to look upon them, may they live,
To ride in triumph in a Dung-cart
And be crowned with all the odious ceremonies belonging to it:
May the cucking stool be their recreation,
And a dungeon their dying chamber,
May they have nine lives like a Cat, to endure this and more;
May they be burnt for witches of a sudden,
And lastly, may the opinion of Philosophers
Prove true, that women have no souls.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p: What husband? at your prayers so seriously?

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.p:
Yes: a few orisons; Friar, thou that standest between
The souls of men and the devil,
Keep these female spirits away,
Or I will renounce my faith else.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: O husband, I little thought to see you in this taking.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
O whore, I little thought to see you in this taking,
I am governor of this castle of cornets,
My grave will be stumbled at, thou adulterate whore,
I might have lived like a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: So you may still husband.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: Peace, thou art very quick with me.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Aye by my faith, and so I am husband,
Belike you know I am with child.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
A bastard, a bastard, a bastard:
I might have lived like a gentleman,
And now I must die like a Hanger on:
Show tricks upon a wooden horse,
And run through an Alphabet of scurvy faces:
Do not expect a good look from me.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: O me unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
O to think whilst we are singing the last Hymn,
And ready to be turned off,
Some new tune is inventing, by some Metre-monger,
To a scurvy Ballad of our death.
Again at our funeral Sermons,
To have the Divine, divide his text into fair branches:
O, flesh and blood cannot endure it,
Yet I will take it patiently like a grave man,
Hangman, tie not my halter of a true lover's knot,
I shall burst it if thou dost.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Husband, I do beseech you on my knees,
I may but speak with you. I will win your pardon,
Or with tears like Niobe bedew a -

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
Hold thy water Crocodile, and say I am bound
To do thee no harm: were I free yet I could not
Be looser than thou: For thou art a whore.
Agamemnons daughter that was sacrificed
For a good wind, felt but a blast of the torments:
Thou shouldest endure, I would make thee swoon
Oftener, than that fellow that by his continual practise
Hopes to become Drum Mayor.
What sayst thou to tickling to death with bodkins?
But thou hast laughed too much at me already, whore.
Justice O Duke, and let me not hang in suspense.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Husband: I will nail me to the earth, but I will
Win your pardon.
My Jewels, jointure, all I have shall fly:
Apparel, bedding, I will not leave a Rug;
So you may come off fairly.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p:
I will come off fairly. Then beg my pardon,
I had rather Surgeon's hall should beg my dead body
For an Anatomy, than thou beg my life:
Justice O Duke, and let us die.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Signior, think, and dally not with heaven,
But freely tell us, did you do the murther?

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
I have confessed it, to my ghostly father,
And done the Sacrament of penance for it.
What would your highness more?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
The like have I, what would your highness more?
And here before you all take it on my death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
In Gods name then on to the death with them,
For the poor widows that you leave behind,
Though by the law, their goods are all confiscate,
Yet we will be their good Lord, and give them them.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.p:
O hell of hells. Why did not we hire some villain to
fire our houses?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
I thought not of that, my mind was altogether of the
gallows.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
May the wealth I leave behind me, help to damn her,
And as the cursed fate of courtesan,
What she gleans with her traded art,
May one as a most due plague cheat from,
In the last dotage of her tired lust,
And leave her an unpitied age of woe.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Watchm.
sp.p: I never heard men pray more fervently.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
O that a man had the instinct of a Lion,
He knows when the Lioness place falls to him:
But these solaces, these women,
They bring man to gray hairs before he be thirty.
Yet they cast out such mists of flattery from their breath,
That a man is lost again; sure I fell into my marriage bed drunk:
Like the Leopard, well with sober eyes would I had avoided it;
Come grave and hide me from my blasted fame;
O that thou couldst as well conceal my shame.

div2.stage: Exeunt Ambo with officers. Women kneele.

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Your pardon and your favour gracious Duke
At once we do implore, that have so long.
Deceived your royal expectation,
Assured that the Comic knitting up,
Will move your spleen, unto the proper use,
Of mirth, your natural inclination:
And wipe away the watery coloured anger,
From your enforced cheek.
Fair Lord, beguile
Them and vouchsafe it, with a pleasing smile.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Now by my life I do, fair Ladies rise,
I never did purpose any other end,
To them and these designs.
I was informed,
Of some notorious error, as I sate in judgment.
And do you hear? these night works require a Cats eyes,
To impierce dejected darkness: call back the prisoners.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.p:
Now what other troubled news,
That we must back thus?
Has any Senator begged my pardon,
Upon my wife's prostitution to him.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
What a spite is this, I had kept in my breath of purpose
Thinking to go away the quieter, and must we now back?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Since you are to die, we will give you winding sheets,
Wherein you shall be shrouded alive,
By which we wind out all these miseries.
Seignior Rogero, bestow a while your eye,
And read here of your true wife's chastity.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p:
Chastity? I will sooner expect a Jesuit's recantation:
Or the great Turks conversion, than her chastity.
Pardon my liege, I will not trust mine eyes:
Women and Devils, will deceive the wise.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The like Sir is apparent on your side.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Who? my wife? chaste? has your grace your sense,
I will sooner believe
A conjurer may say his prayers with zeal,
Than her honesty. Had she been an Hermaphrodite
I would scarce hath given credit to you,
Let him that hath drunk love drugs trust a woman,
By heaven I think, the air is not more common.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Then we impose a strict command upon you:
On your Allegiance, read what there is writ.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A writ of error, on my life my liege.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You will find it so I fear.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What have we here the Art of Brachigraphy?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
He is stung already, as if his eyes were turned on Persies shield.
There motion is fixed, like to the poole of Stix.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p:
Yonder is our flames, and from the hollow Arches,
Of his quick eyes, comes comet trains of fire:
Bursting like hidden furies, from their Canes,
Yours till he sleep, the sleep of all
The world, Rogero.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: Marry and that Lethargy seize you, read again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Thy servant so made by his stars, Rogero.
A fire on your wandering stars Rogero.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Sathan, why hast thou tempted my wife?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Peace, seducer, I am branded in the forehead
With your star mark. May the stars drop upon thee,
And with their sulphur vapours choke thee, ere thou
Come at the gallows.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p: Stretch not my patience Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Clarid.
sp.p: Termagant that will stretch thy patience.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
Had I known this I would have poisoned thee in
the Chalice,
This morning, when we received the Sacrament.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.p:
Slave, knowest thou this? it is an Appendix to the Letter,
But the greater temptation is hidden within.
I will scour thy gorge like a Hawk: thou shalt swallow thine own stone in this letter,
Sealed and delivered in the presence of.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Keep them asunder, list to us, we command.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.p:
O violent villain, is not thy hand hereto?
And writ in blood to show thy raging lust?

sp.speaker: Thais.
sp.p:
Spice of a new halter, when you go a-ranging thus like
Devils, would you might burn for it as they do.

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
Thus it is to lie with another man's wife:
He shall be sure to hear of it again.
But we are friends, sweet duck,
And this shall be my maxim all my life,
MAN never happy is till in a wife.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.p:
Here sunk our hate lower than any whirlpool.
And this chaste kiss I give thee for thy care.
That fame of women full as wise as fair.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
You have saved us a labour in your love.
But Gentlemen, why stood you so preposterously?
Would you have headlong run to Infamy,
In so defamed a death?

sp.speaker: Rogero.
sp.p:
O my Liege, I had rather roar to death with Phaleris
Bull, than Darius-like, to have one of my wings extend to Atlas, the other to Europa.
What is a Cuckold learn of me,
Few can tell his pedigree,
Nor his subtle nature conster,
Born a man, but dies a monster.
Yet great Antiquaries say,
They spring from our Methusala,
Who after Noahs flood was found,
To have his Crest with branches crowned,
God in Eden's happy shade,
This same creature made.
Then to cut off all mistaking,
Cuckolds are of women's making.
From whose snares, good Lord deliver us.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.p:
Amen, Amen.
Before I would prove a Cuckold, I would endure a winters Pilgrimage in the Frozen Zone,
Go stark naked through Muscouia, where the Climate is degrees colder than Ice.
And thus much to all married men.
Now I see great reason why
Love should marry jealousy:
Since man's best of life is fame,
He had need preserve the same.
When it is in a woman's keeping,
Let not Argos eyes be sleeping.
The pox is unto Panders given
By the better powers of heaven.
That contains pure chastity,
And each Virgin sovereignty,
Wantonly she oped and lost:
Gift whereof, a God might boast.
Therefore shouldst thou Diana wed,
Yet be jealous of her bed.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Night, like a Masque, is entered heaven's great hall,
With thousand Torches ushering the way:
To Risus will we consecrate this Evening,
Like Missermis cheating of the brack.
We will make this night the day. Fair joys befall
Us and our Actions. Are you pleased all?
